author: {'steamid': '76561197966486404', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 22, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1710665019}
review:
I love the Trials games, and have done since playing Trials HD 15 years ago... I was so excited to pick up Trials Fusion in the sale, and it even works on steam deck. It performs well, the controls respond well and it looks fantastic. Except it's a copout.
All the online services are switched off, but Ubisoft won't confirm or deny this officially. Fine: I can live without online multiplayer, leaderboards and even Track Central, ugh. This is already a huge hit: the most effective way to improve is to watch replays from further up the leaderboard. But surely I can at least chase my own replays and eke out improvements to get the platinum medals, right?! NO! It doesn't even store basic things like run times, so it's impossible to see if you're even improving. No personal ghosts, no personal records. The only thing it stores is which medals and challenges you've achieved.
This game has been nerfed in the most irritating, petulant, childish way. It's the 21st century: we have this magic that lets games store some data locally AND some data in the cloud. And yet Ubisoft don't seem to have figured this out.
I keep playing this for 20-30 mins every so often and every time I hit a track I can't nail the medal on first time, and start wanting to see how I'm progressing towards the next medal I get irritated and give up. Today I'm annoyed enough to write this review.

Don't buy this game, unless you enjoy being frustrated by the spiteful way this game was crippled.

author: {'steamid': '76561199203302588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1701569687}
review: Played the original port on Xbox360 and had an absolute blast playing it, figured I'd pick it up here on PC as well. Visually it's still a nicely detailed game that should perform well on a variety of builds. General gameplay is fun and challenging and will easily keep you entertained for hours. The problem with the PC port and why the playerbase has (somewhat) understandably abandoned the game is because of the nonstop circus that is Ubisoft. Unfortunately in order to run the game you must use Ubisoft's god awful launcher uconnect (or some sh*t). This is an automatic turn off for many, and understandably so. And unfortunately this has all but crippled the online scene in the game. I wish their was an option for a middle of the road review option but sadly there isn't. Overall I can't recommend the PC port of this game. Just play it on Xbox360 or XB1, unless you get this game for a really good deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067317556', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1634861690}
review:
I bought this game years ago. Loved it. Didn't need Ubisoft account. Then one day I did, so I made one. I eventually deleted the email associated with that account. Now I am unable to access Ubisoft's launcher to play the game I bought. I put in a ticket a while back and they responded weeks after the fact. The email went into spam, and they closed the ticket. This happened numerous times till I eventually gave up. Fast forward to now, I decided I wanted to try again, so I put in another ticket with Ubisoft. This time, after a few days waiting, they sent an email asking if I still needed help. I responded that I indeed still needed help. A few days later they sent a similar email asking if I still needed help, which I told them I did. I received an email the next day telling me they sent a code to the email associated with my account. I responded by informing them that, as stated in the initial ticket, that I do not have access to the email, as I had deleted the email. Within minutes they resent the email the exact same email, telling me they sent the code to the initial email. I responded harshly this time, conveying the same idea, but with an immense amount of displeasure. Within minutes, they sent the exact same email again. I responded tersely that the email was deleted and that I couldn't undelete emails. They responded quickly telling me that they know that I don't have access to the email, that they weren't asking me to have access to the email, and that because they couldn't verify that I had indeed purchased the game that they were closing the ticket. 
I have never in my life been so insulted. I know I might have been harsh in one of the email, but having had this problem for YEARS, it is only to be expected. There is absolutely no recourse whatsoever. I am out the money I spent on Trials Fusion, Trials Rising, and Trails 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058413662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1696795589}
review:
[code]The Trials games are the definition of ‚Äúeasy to learn, hard to master‚Äù and Trials Fusion is no exception, providing lots of 2.5D platforming racing fun as long as you can keep up with the difficulty curve[/code]

When asked about racing games that are easy to pick up, a common answer would be the [i]Mario Kart[/i] franchise. And it‚Äôs a good answer, since the games are kid-friendly, work with basic rules that are easy to understand and offer controls that are easy to grasp. Coincidentally, that‚Äôs exactly what the [i]Trials[/i] franchise offers as well. They‚Äôre kid-friendly games (maybe less so than [i]Mario Kart[/i] but still), with easy-to-understand basic rules and accessible controls, yet no one would recommend picking those games instead ‚Äì and for good reason.

For one, [i]Trials[/i] is less about racing in the traditional way and more about platforming ‚Äì instead of simply getting to the goal the fastest, you‚Äôll also have to overcome various obstacles on your way. Understands the physics is most important here, as you‚Äôll only get lean forwards/backwards while accelerating/braking on your motocross. The controls are simple but precise and in order to make it past the various obstacles, ranging from simple ramps to entire canyons, you‚Äôll have to master them. The 2.5D [i]Trials[/i] games might even feel like platforming puzzles at times, where you have to figure out just the right momentum and position to make an accurate jump. And this is the main reason why [i]Trials[/i] is no [i]Mario Kart[/i] ‚Äì after a slow and easy start, the difficulty quickly ramps up and reaches devilish heights.

[i]Trials Fusion[/i], the fifth game in the franchise, is no exception to this of course, featuring everything that‚Äôs expected of the series by now. The big innovations lie elsewhere ‚Äì a new sci-fi setting, which allows for a lot of varied stage backdrops, the addition of a stunt system and even the inclusion of a story told through audio logs during each stage. Unfortunately, the sci-fi setting is the only feature out of these three that‚Äôs actually an improvement over the previous [i]Trials[/i] games.

[i]Trials Fusion[/i] offers various modes to engage in: there‚Äôs a single-player career mode, which unlocks new vehicles, local and online multiplayer and even a stage editor, where users can create and share their own tracks. In the following, I‚Äôll focus on the career mode, as that‚Äôs the heart of the game.

Career mode consists of eight locations, which all offer about 6-8 stages including tutorials (‚ÄúTraining Programs‚Äù), FMX stages and minigame stages (e.g. throw your driver off the motocross as far as you can). These stages range from ‚ÄúEasy‚Äù to ‚ÄúExpert‚Äù difficulty, although harder stages are locked at first. To unlock them, you have to earn a certain number of medals by completing stages. If you meet certain requirements while finishing a stage, e.g. finishing under a certain time and with no crashes, you‚Äôll earn more medals. Additionally, most change offer additional challenges, like finding secret exits or finishing a stage only by accelerating/braking, which can be quite enjoyable (or frustrating) but are also completely optional if you just want to progress.

As I mentioned before, the sci-fi setting is a big win here, as it allows for some truly creative stage backdrops. Instead of race-platforming through muddy arenas, it‚Äôs now possible to race through volcanoes, jump through the jungle at sunset or even perform tricks on the roofs of a futuristic city! No stage looks and plays the same, which means that trying out a new stage is always a lot of fun at first ‚Äì and going for the best time in order to reach the maximum number of medals in a stage quite addicting.

As you progress through the early career mode locations, you‚Äôll unlock more tutorials ‚Äì and more vehicles to control. Unfortunately, you‚Äôll also notice that many stages restrict the vehicle selection to two or three choices, which means you‚Äôre still going to be stuck with the same bikes for the most part. The FMX system is introduced as well, which allows you to do stunts while driving ‚Äì some stages are pure FMX stages, where you need to perform a certain number of tricks to earn your medals, instead of simply reaching the end the fastest. This sounds nice in theory but is a pain in practice, simply because the controls for the stunts won‚Äôt work well enough.

As the difficulty of [i]Trials Fusion[/i] rises through the early chapters, another problem becomes apparent. The story of the game is told through audio messages while proceeding through the stages. However, these audio logs get cut off and won‚Äôt repeat if you reset the stage or go back to the latest checkpoint. As such, unless you want exit and restart the entire stage every time you missed an audio log or complete every stage without resetting once, you‚Äôre most likely going to miss most of the story ‚Äì though it‚Äôs not really the main focus of the game to begin with.

Once you‚Äôve completed the career stages up to the ‚Äúmedium‚Äù difficulty, you‚Äôll have encountered tracks with a very nice flow, an addictive medal system and optional challenges, all set to diverse stages featuring some truly unique obstacles and backdrops. However, once you reach the tracks that the game classifies as ‚Äúhard‚Äù, everything changes dramatically.

While the difficulty curve has been increasing slowly but surely so far, it suddenly takes a drastic jump upwards. While every stage up to that point could‚Äôve been completed by properly accelerating/braking and controlling your position, advanced maneuvers - like bunny hops - are now necessary in order to progress through the stages. And just like that, the platforming aspect of [i]Trials Fusion[/i] takes center-stage and requires you to put in some serious efforts.

The rampant difficulty change and the requirements for advanced movement techniques make the second half of [i]Trials Fusion[/i] feel like an entirely different game. Sure, the advanced maneuvers have been taught through tutorials before, but pulling them off precisely & continuously during a stage is something else entirely. While earlier stages might‚Äôve taken up to two minutes to complete, a newcome is likely to spend more than twenty minutes just to finish a stage once. And that‚Äôs not mentioning the ‚ÄúExtreme‚Äù stages, which are even more unforgiving. 

Needless to say, that from this point on, [i]Trials Fusion[/i] can be extremely frustrating. You either accept the challenge and suffer (unless you‚Äôre already a franchise veteran) or you give up. And while it's perfectly fine to challenges to the most dedicated of players, it‚Äôs still a shame that [i]Trials Fusion[/i] didn‚Äôt provide a smooth difficulty curve in order to get new players accustomed to these challenges ‚Äì instead, it‚Äôs do or die. A small ray of hope: If you only care about unlocking all stages, getting gold medals in all easier stages up to that point is more than enough.

Concluding, [i]Trials Fusion[/i] is a fun 2.5D racing-platformer with a lot of great and diverse stages offering a nice flow. However, the new FMX system suffers due to bad controls, the game limits the number of vehicles during most stages, the storytelling attempts are constantly broken and the difficulty curve is more than uneven, which keeps the game from being a masterpiece overall - but it‚Äôs still a lot of unique fun you won‚Äôt find anywhere outside of this franchise. Unfortunately, this version on Steam doesn't offer SteamCloud support for saves and enforces Ubisoft Connect as a second launcher, so buying the console version of the game might be preferrable to some.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980785450', 'num_games_owned': 2605, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1693450362}
review:
[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/245490/Trials_Fusion/]Trials Fusion‚Ñ¢[/url][/b] is the second best Trials game on Steam!

It's an arcade [i]motorcyle trials[/i] game, with obstacles, stunts, goals, and fun (and funny) events.  It plays very well and looks fantastic.  But on the downside it had problems with saving my progress, so I had to set it to offline mode (which raised another problem of a popup showing up after every race, telling me to go back online).

I purchased this game, along with [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/220160/Trials_Evolution_Gold_Edition/]Trials Evolution: Gold Edition[/url], and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/641080/Trials_Rising/]Trials¬Æ Rising[/url], to find out which game would work best on the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/steamdeck]Steam Deck[/url].  For all of the games I had to set them to run in [b]Proton Experimental[/b] ([url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/220160/Trials_Evolution_Gold_Edition/]Trials Evolution: Gold Edition[/url] ([b]the best Trials game on Steam[/b]) had no problems, but [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/641080/Trials_Rising/]Trials¬Æ Rising[/url] got stuck at a black screen after the Ubisoft Connect login).

However, there is one major problem when running this game on the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/steamdeck]Steam Deck[/url], and that is the problem of the [url=https://ubisoftconnect.com/en-US/]Ubisoft Connect[/url] software, that asks for you to log in with your email and password [i]every single time you start the game (and sometimes your password twice - just to be sure ü§¶‚Äç), and it refuses to remember them, even though you explicitly tell it to remember your credentials[/i]. This client is an absolute piece of üí© that needs to have the source code tossed into a volcano, or placed on the next rocket being fired into the Sun.  

This poor client, along with the saving problem significantly impacted the score, which otherwise may have been a perfect score.  I debated keeping this game because of the problems, but I decided I will keep it and work through these problems.

[h1]7/10[/H1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197994002775', 'num_games_owned': 6537, 'num_reviews': 1438, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1686146437}
review:
Trials Fusion continues the line of the previous Trials games and does so without dropping stitches.
You can have fun again with many different tracks and challenges, some of which are really challenging, which can lead to a lot of frustration.
Fortunately, the fun factor of Trials Fusion weighs much more heavily, and you will soon forget those annoying moments when you whiz through the levels at great speeds. Trials Fusion hits the mark!

The game also works well on the steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLawa9QmtAI

New in Fusion is the ability to perform tricks. This is done by throwing the right analog stick on the controller in one direction.
The legs of the driver go in the direction you point.
A funny effect, but unfortunately this control method makes it somewhat difficult to perform certain tricks with precision. The races in which tricks matter are sometimes very frustrating because of this.
Some jumps and transitions are very precisely thought out and only possible in one way.
Sometimes you have to try a challenge many times where you see your bike sliding into the descent often enough, this can be really frustrating.
To make it even more competitive, you also see a 'ghost' of your friends riding the track and if you see that they succeed and you get stuck, it is difficult to keep the controller intact.

Trials Fusion welcomes every gamer with open arms and shows a humorous sci-fi world where you race and stunt freely.
But as soon as you don't pay attention and feel Zen on the track, suddenly more is expected of you.
The addictive tour de force of gold medals and perfect scores then turns into a frustrating task full of revenge.
The non-committal gives way to repetition, and a good dose of practice becomes compulsory. That is not for everyone, but it gives the fanatical drivers a lot of satisfaction.

author: {'steamid': '76561199239158232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1692870372}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983652083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1694292816}
review:
Edit:
I wrote the below review after playing for about 1¬Ω hour, and things seemed to be working great.
HOWEVER!
The next day, Ubisoft Connect seems to have lost my save file. No trace of it.
Well that's not technically true. Even though my progress and settings were wiped, my TIMES for my previously completed tracks was still there. So I had to race against my own ghost for a map the game doesn't acknowledge me even completing.
This was annoying to say the least.

Googling the issue, it seems to stem from cloud saves in Ubisoft Connect. Disabling this in Ubisofts client seems to prevent it from wiping my progress again.
I don't think it's necessarily the game's fault though.

All things considered, it's still a fun game and I still recommend it.
I would like to give a big high five to Redlynx for an awesome game,
and a big middle finger to Ubisoft for ruining everything good in the world.

Original review:
Works perfectly well on a PC, unlike what a lot of other reviews are saying. If there were issues with U-play at the time, those issues have since been resolved. Sure it's annoying to need U-play even if you bought it on Steam, but what are you gonna do?
Can't speak for the handheld toy some are complaining about though..

All this being said, it's a lot of fun to blast around on a bike! And as with most games, it only gets better with friends!
It is currently on a 75% sale, so what are you doing down here? The "Buy"-button is near the top!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966958625', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1699592112}
review:
This game is a a bit difficult IMO.  Now, I'm 55 years old and don't have the reflexes I did when 20 years ago but that's not the problem with this game.  If you're running Windows 10 you may have to do some tweaking to get it to run.  I had to find the .exe change the compatibility mode to Windows 7.  I also added "    -windowed    " to the command line argument.  Then I started Ubisoft Connect BEFORE running Trials Fusion.  At some point the game started, asked me for me password which I remember.... and the thing finally started, switched settings to ULTRA and the game decided to cooperate.

Now then, I bought this years ago.  You can go ahead and EXPECT some issues unless you're running Windows XP or something LOL.  I got lucky and managed to get it to run again.

I have to give this game a definitely LOW score like 3 out of 10.
It sucks to buy a game, spend over an hour just trying to get it to RUN only to find out that you can't get refunded because you "PLAYED THE GAME FOR OVER AN HOUR" but in reality you spent 3 hours pulling your hair out, searching the Discussions, searching the net.....

I'd just pass on this game if I didn't already own it.
Evolutions GOLD is much more stable and just as fun.

review:
A seriously very underrated game it's absolutely fantastic from the soundtrack to the gameplay. It however does have a fair share of cons like the tutorials they were alright but the one that bugged me the most was the FMX it just felt a bit janky for some reason and the customisation like others have said only being available if you are connected online however I haven't faced that problem yet as I've never played this game offline before and feel no reason to do so.

Overall this game has made my blood boil and also has made me swear from left to right just trying to complete a hard or extreme difficulty level but it is worth it since this game is banging.

I found some workarounds online and in the forums, but none of them worked for me. It shows that it is deck verified, but I'd recommend avoiding this for deck until it gets fixed.

Get this game when it's on sale and you will have an amazing time :]

author: {'steamid': '76561198081261645', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 6285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2642, 'last_played': 1682290825}
review:
You press left and right to lean, up and down to accelerate and reverse. A series of short (usually 2-3 minutes) obstacle filled tracks you must navigate your bike over without crashing.

-You don't need to beat every level to access all the content; the end-game levels are there for the psychotic players.
-The highest skill ceiling of any game I've ever played.
-BEAUTIFUL environmental design. I could just idle at the start of the track staring at the scenery.
-The end-game levels are so difficult I dont think I'll ever complete them.
-Impossible not to try and do flips off jumps and nail the landing. Seriously fun.
-Did I mention the ridiculous skill ceiling? Holy geez I dont know who those tracks are for.

-Good game if you have general anxiety because forces you to practice mindfulness; you focus on one small thing and theres nothing beyond that one small thing you need to think about. Just get your bike over the crate; no worrying about maximizing resource yield, or fussing over how to set the early game up to maximize the late game.
-Good game for studying with. The game loop is /very/ short so its the perfect little sip of pop you take for every 15 minutes of studying you do. Perfect attention refocuser.

author: {'steamid': '76561198241476788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1677041703}
review: Poor tutorials, annoying dialogue/story, Uplay, gatekeeping harder tracks behind a medals system forcing you to replay old content. The biggest turn off for me are the expert tracks, the game makes no effort to explain how to do the tricks you need to finish the courses. Paired with the fact most of these expert courses are just tedious requiring computer perfect inputs makes them a complete failure in terms of challenge. I got bronze on all but the last 2 expert tracks and gave up. Its not fun to play since idk what the game wants from me until I look up youtube videos. Watching replays of other people completing the tracks isn't helpful since you cant learn anything from them, cant see inputs or go frame by frame so why even include em?

author: {'steamid': '76561198072071878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1674439110}
review:
[h1]Axeploseph Review Form(v1.0)[/h1]
[h3]_____________________[/h3]
[h3]Product:[/h3] Trials Fusion - Deluxe Edition
[h3]Review Form #[/h3] 1
[h3]_____________________[/h3]

[h2]Why I purchased:[/h2] The guy I bought my first gaming PC from suggested the series (I asked if he had any suggestions) and said this was the newest one coming out so I decided to try it out.

[h2]Price I paid:[/h2] [-25%] $29.99 on Steam (Summer 2014)

[h2]When did I play:[/h2] Most of my playtime was from when I first bought it. I have launched it a few times over the years whenever I get nostalgic about my early days on Steam.

[h2]Thoughts:[/h2] Fun genre (sidescrolling dirtbike games) to play every now and again. The physics make it feel a little more rewarding but mostly just have me in awe of the videos of people who are elite at this game.

The aesthetic is nice, the challenge is there. It's straight forward and can be enjoyable but also forgettable. I got ~60% of the way through career mode with all golds before I quit being so meticulous and the difficulty started spiking (for me). The game starts lagging pretty badly for me and regardless of what I change in the settings the performance seems sub optimal.

Most of this is coming from memory as I played this game for the first time in a few years and thought about how I should really review some games. Trying out a new format and hoping it pays off helping me review games more consistently and hoping it is somewhat more helpful to those reading this.

[h2]Did I finish the game? If not, do I plan on finishing the game?:[/h2] No, I'm ~60% of the way through career mode, the difficulty is going up and it sometimes starts lagging really badly despite fiddling with settings. I usually find myself disinterested after 5-10 minutes in-game. There are better Trials games than this one.

[h2]Was it worth it:[/h2] No, if I knew then what I knew now I would've done more research and come to the conclusion that Urban Trial Freestyle was a much better game and just gone with that. I would've passed on this altogether unless I was itching for a game like this and it was cheap on sale.

[h2]Funny/notable moment/memory from game:[/h2] None that I can recall, just that when I see it in my library it makes me nostalgic about when I first came to Steam, but I rarely feel the urge to play it and if I do, I usually lose interest either before or not long after it finishes installing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047849953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5154, 'last_played': 1676424660}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083514705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1706373213}
review:
Why do Ubisoft hate this platform?
I played this game on PS4 for years and never had any problems. Recently I decided to switch back to PC... what a nightmare. First of all you have to enter your Ubisoft thing password every time you start the game, but it will start only if you're lucky because most of the time it will ask you to enter the password once more, and sometimes it will decide that you are not trustworthy or something and will send a code to your email and then you have to enter the code, your email and your password. If you're not frustrated enough by then, sometimes the game will decide to lag terribly when you start it and you have no choice but to restart it and guess what, you have to enter your password, at least once, again.
But my biggest gripe is that the tournaments are not supported on PC - you can play them but with no rewards, so almost nobody is playing them, while on PS4 hundreds are playing them. Btw PS4 is a last gen console.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035893622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6563, 'last_played': 1702190022}
review:
The game itself is challenging, yet super fun and rewarding. The game's levels are crafted in a way that slowly introduces you to more complicated techniques without ever throwing too much at you at once. If you enjoy dirtbikes, stunts, and basically puzzling through fun and unique levels then you'll love this game. Its super rewarding to shave fractions of a second off a level and especially rewarding when you finally beat a level without any checkpoints.

I wish Steam allowed caveats, or perhaps tags on reviews. Sometimes you look at a game's review rating and the game appears to be horrible but in reality the reviews are all basically unrelated to the actual gameplay.  This is the case here, at least in my opinion. 

The negative reviews all seem to focus on two main issues. The main problem people have is the game is actually launched through a secondary launcher called uPlay. I have never had any issue with this, but apparently it causes issues if you are using a SteamDeck. I would prefer there was no uPlay requirement, but at the end of the day it doesn't affect my experience at all on the PC.

The second issue people have is I believe Ubisoft shut down the multiplayer aspect of the game. Personally that doesn't bother me as I exclusively play solo, but I can see how that would be a big negative for some people. 

Basically, if you don't care about multiplayer, aren't using a SteamDeck, and find the idea of a challenging yet rewarding dirtbike game with stunts, loops, jumps, explosions, etc, then this game is 100% worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082764480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 418, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1660479343}
review: Trials Fusion is a platforming racing game where you control a motorcycle. It is a completely unique formula and seems like a weird combination but they flawlessly made it work. The game is about clearing the challenging levels fast and crashing as little as possible. The level designs are phenomenal and each level flows so well when you figure out how to approach it. The levels have multiple difficulties ranging from easy to extreme. I must say that Trials team might be the only developer who actually rates the difficulty logically. I started the game trying to get gold medals on all levels then quickly realized that wasn't so easy to do when i got to the harder levels. People who are looking for challenges will be really satisfied of this game. Also the game is really rich in content even if you don't buy the dlc's thanks to it having a level editor. There are over 200000 user created levels that you can play if you can't get enough after finishing the main game. It also has multiplayer, tournaments although its quite dead and most importantly local multiplayer for up to 4 players playing simultaneously. Trials Fusion is a super fun game that anyone can have fun with. Recommended for everyone since the massive library of levels it has easily makes it worth your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021980180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1657197894}
review:
It feels almost redundant to talk about how "janky" a game made by RedLynx is, but it has to be mentioned, regardless.

This game [and the follow-up,  "Trials Rising"] have glitches that have literally been plaguing the competitive and casual playerbase of these games for nearly 20 years. It's simply astonishing that they haven't found a fix for the dreaded "Tire Glitch" instead of, say, making poorly-built minigames that hardly work, and "meme" bikes to milk you of the micro-transaction currency du jour. Yes, this game AND Rising have MTX components, and they're pretty scummy ones, at that.

It also uses Ubisoft's pathetic DRM service and launcher, so that's a "bonus".

This game is also the most.. uninspired one, visually speaking. Every level has a "future" aesthetic to go with the game's theme, but it's so sterile and lifeless that it's actually worth getting angry about, because the editor and it's tools are amazing. They actively CHOSE to make this game look as bland and repetitive as possible. It's astonishing, really.

The AI voiceover is incredibly aggravating, but thankfully, you can turn her off in the Options menu.

Just buy Trials: Evolution. It doesn't have the expansions that the 360 version had, but it's still the best Trials game, by a country mile. If I were to guess, looking at the 'trajectory' of the Trials series, the next installment might actually be the worst game of all time.

Well done, RedLynx. I wanna love your games, but god, you make it f*cking difficult.

EDIT: Oh god, how could I have forgotten the "FMX" features in this game? Literally the worst thing I've ever seen in a game, with regards to working as intended. It's a god-damn mess that nobody liked. Well-spent dev time, guys. Great job(!)

review: DO NOT BUY. For over two months, the servers for this game have been down, making core features such as posting new times to leaderboards and playing user-created tracks in Track Central impossible. To make matters worse, Ubisoft and RedLynx have failed to provide any help or relevant information regarding the issue. I will happily change my review if things turn around, but unfortunately, the future for this game doesn't look very bright.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000926145', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 75774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60262, 'last_played': 1708677952}
review:
NEW REVIEW

You killed my favorite game you bastards. They turned off the user track central and online progress in general. This game was kept alive because of it's user track central which had dozens of thousands of tracks created with passion and dedication from it's fateful fans. Now it's all gone. F you...


OLD REVIEW

Good game, especially if you're a bit of a gear head. Once you get good enough and can take on ninja level 1's and 2's mechanically without thinking too much about it, then you can listen to podcasts in the background. Perfect game to kill time and/or learn something while you're doing it.
Definitely buy this one over Trials Rising, it's much more intuitive and is not a broken mess.

review:
It's very hard to be polite to Uplay!
Every time I try to play this game, Uplay force me to wait for it update. After that, it fails to login, when I go offline, another updating, then it says I have no game purchased!
Then I try to go online again, another updating, another login fails.... on and on! I can't play my game!
So wtf is going on here?!
I just want to play game on steam only, why tf Uplay is in charge?
.....
Two days after...
Thank God, now I've finally entered this game successfully.
But I'm not satisfied anymore, somehow...

author: {'steamid': '76561198085792193', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1619126108}
review:
Nope, not worth it. Yes this is a fun bike acrobacy and balance game with real good challanges and online features like racing against ghosts of the players in the leaderboards. You can easily rewind the last checkpoint to retry. The game gives you enough amount of training. But that is all there is.

The physics is nonsensical. This game creates a force out of nowhere. This is not challenge, this is just weird.
The rider costomization is pay to get.
The DLC is too expensive.
The progression is locked behind the number of gold or silver bars which are hard to get.
You can't play a track more than 30 minutes or so.
You can't retry more than 500 times in a race.

The game tried to be challenging and innovative. It has small fun touches here and there and i admire them. But after a certain point, you will say "why bother with this weird physics".

author: {'steamid': '76561198063936174', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 18607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18607, 'last_played': 1618277871}
review:
If you've never heard about Trials then I think this is a good starting point. This is the definition of easy to learn and hard to master. Just a few simple inputs yet so complex once you get deeply into it. You'll find yourself racing the same track over and over again, just to get that extra medal, or just to prove that you can further improve your best time. I had lots of fun while playing it and I'd recommend it to whoever is thinking about buying it.

This game is my favourite out of all the Trials franchise. Yeah Evo was good but this one looks a lot better  and the Pit Viper bike is awesome driving-wise. The mini-game tracks are very fun to play (except Big Air) and the sense of acomplishment once you get that platinum medal is the fuel that will keep you going.

Do not buy this game if you're looking for an online experience. The community is almost non-existent and the ones who are still grinding will probably smoke you. However, that doesn't change the fact that this game is very fun to play and grind for many hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299046072', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3474, 'last_played': 1618253798}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047337385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2062, 'last_played': 1493285339}
review: I love Trials as a series. Evolution being my favorite by a longshot, followed by Rising, followed by HD, and finally by Fusion. It may rank at the bottom in my eyes, but that doesn't mean it's a bad game. It just didn't capture quite the same magic as Evolution did, or HD (being the first that I played). The controls are a bit floatier, the maps a lot less memorable, the mini-games no longer mindblowing or at least subjectively as interesting. It's a good addition to the series if all you want is more trials - but I couldn't into it like I could its predecessors, and is the only game I didn't feel compelled to get platinums on every single level (which I did for HD, Evolution [except inferno 3...] and half of Rising).

review:
I absolutely love the Trials Series and I think that Fusion is among the best ever made. the community a few years back was electric! (especially on the Xbox servers) I used to go under the handle SkinZInTheHood, made tonnes of tracks in the much improved track creator., T E C H N I C O L O U R , Lethal Heights II and Wrong Turn are some of my favourites to name a few! 

 I highly Recommend this game!

review:
Trails was one of my favourite games series of the 360. Highly recommend,  easy to pick up but hard to master!
Not checked in for a while but these games had one of the best communities I have encountered. 
Most of my time by the end was spent in the 'track builder', the ability to share your creations & see the amazing work from other players was so much fun.

review: Absolute waste of time and money. To play this trash it forces you to download Ubisoft client, the FPS is capped at 60 and with no option to change it to 144 so all the players with a 144hz monitor can go eat feces, and because of that the screen is tearing all the time and it looks very ugly, there's a vsync option but it does not work. The graphics look like trash and the textures are low resolution. The UI is confusing and annoying to navigate. Its just not fun its not as cool as i thought it would be, don't buy this game, its not worth 19$! I would not play it even if it was free.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977843764', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1366, 'last_played': 1629648339}
review:
Gameplay is great. Definitely bring patience and expect to fail a lot in the harder levels. The learning curve gets steeper as the levels get harder. Mastering the movements required to overcome the tougher obstacles is very satisfying. If you like beeing challenged and improving your times on the leaderboard, this game is fantastic.

However I do not recommend the game because the UbiSoft Support is absolutely terrible. My Pre-Order Items were suddenly missing even though I had them back in 2014. After a bunch of tickets they sent me to Steam Support and the Steam Support refers back to UbiSoft-Support in an endless cycle. Beeing pretty experienced in problem solving on PCs I eventually out figured that deleting my savegame and disabling cloudsave made those items appear in my game again. You wouldn't expect Pre-Order items to be bound to a savefile. And I was told by the Ubi-Support that there is nothing they can do. So much for that.

After I finally had visual access to those items again, the Bikeskin suddenly cost realmoney currency to unlock. Note: I had both items unlocked in 2014, even wearing them on my old Leaderboard replays. Because I somewhat invested a decent amount of time into the game I bought a 1000 Acorn pack to unlock said item, for a second time. Unfortunately I completed the purchase while the game was running in the background and I never recieved the currency ingame. UbiSoft Support claims that I have recieved it and there is no way for me to prove them wrong because the game has no ingame transaction history. The Real money currency is probably also bound to savefile/cloudsave rather than your UPlay account and my guess is that it replaced my value with the one I had before buying the currency when I closed the game, because spaghetti code. The UPlay store then said that the packs only work with basegames purchased in their store and I have the steam version, no refund, my money is just gone.

If you're interested into a Trials game I would recommend getting Trials Evolution instead. It has no microtransactions.

review:
I was a bit disappointed. I am an old "veteran" from the old trials games and i think this game is "too modern". 
The physics got way too complicated. The old-school games were difficult, but simple. In Trials Fusion you can find all sorts of crazy graphics effects and really well-designed maps, but i feel like it takes away the charm of the game. Unfortunate. I played a lot of trials 2 recently and got bored, so i purchased fusion, but went back to playing the same maps over and over again getting a better time in trials 2. lol.

I really love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133386118', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 14693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14678, 'last_played': 1692047803}
review:
Reading through the many other reviews this game has, I can surely say that probably 50% of the 44% of bad reviews are just lazy people complaining about Uplay not allowing them to play and the other 50% being people that can't get over themselves to try and learn the game. While yes, the Uplay stuff a pretty annoying and useless step, literally all you have to do is login and you're set; most of the time it even remembers you. If you can't seem to figure out how to create an account and login to Uplay, then I suggest uninstalling the game, shutting down Steam, restarting your PC, opening up YouTube, and heading over to the Cocomelon channel.

In all seriousness, though, it seems like the most gripes people have with this masterpiece are:
1. They're bad
2. They don't want to learn how to get better so instead they play the easy maps and get bored
3. They blame the game for running poorly instead of their 1995 Dell All-In-One
4. it's too hawd xd

For those that can't sit down and read some words for more than 15 seconds, here's a pros/cons list:

Pros:
- Interesting and intriguing story line
- One of the best soundtracks ever made
- Amazing control over the bikes
- Great graphics that really can give an amazing sense of atmosphere
- Fun and interesting levels that never get boring and are never copy-pasted
- Spectacular DLC (not the unicorn one, that one's alright)
- 10/10 on the nostalgia scale
- Fun and new local MP tracks

Game Cons:
- Uplay

Player-related Cons:
- Dead game since Rising succeeded it, so there's not much activity in the map workshop anymore
- Only local MP


The best things in this game become apparent when you starting racking up more than 0.5 hours in the game. For example, the game actually has a story! Crazy how people miss this, given that it's literally shoved in your face the first map you launch. It's a great story, though. Perfect amount of detail, storytelling, and pacing, balanced with an adequate amount of "what the hell is going on". Again, the more you play, the more story you learn about, and it's actually really interesting, in my opinion.

As for the actual mechanics of the game, they're amazing. Aside from CS:GO, I don't think I've played any other game that has controls that are so responsive and allow you to feel so connected with the bike. Once you start unlocking bikes, especially the Pit Viper, the game starts to get really awesome. The Pit Viper's in-game quote, "Requires precision control. Once tamed, can move like mercury," does not lie, and upon trying it is probably the point at which a lot of people ragequit and come here to write a negative review.

I'm lazy and not going to proofread this to see if I covered all the topics, so JUST GO PLAY IT!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031556867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1599860981}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976375683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 114088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77455, 'last_played': 1688478917}
review:
Probably the best entry in the series, tied with Trials Evo for bike "feel" - Bought Trials Rising but my save games got broken somehow and lost everything I played for, all my items I won from pretty much all of the challenges in the game. Fusion was a bit rocky at launch but nowhere near as broken as Rising is, plus the bike feels like it's got steel rods instead of actual suspension.., and the wheels feel like they're made from wood instead of inflated rubber. Evo and Fusion are the best in the series with regards to game play mechanics. 

Track central is so much better as well, Risings TC is just poor for such a big game, shame really as I've put 1300 hours in to Fusion and got turned off Rising after maybe 20-40 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112495234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 741, 'last_played': 1708651251}
review:
The Reviews on here are weird. 
Most of the bad ones (and the first listed) are from when game was first released, and Yes I got it on release with Xbox 360. As with all sequels, it's hard to live up to originals straight away... Bet people moaned about EVO. No "it's not like HD"
Fusion is great game, never problem running it, either orig on xbox and now on pc.
This game has aged well with the patches and DLC's and the track editor I always thought was brilliant. 
Why do people moan about microtransactions in this game? It's purely only on a few cosmetics otherwise has no effect. Who plays trials for the dressing up, if you do, get a life! 
Great game and great track central. If you want a game that's now cheap and fun to play, you can't go wrong!

review: It's a fun arcade style biking game. What more can you really say about it? It's a lot more fun on multiplayer, particularly if you have friends over to play it with you (speaking from experience cause I've gone to my friend's house to play it and generally have much more fun there than I do playing it alone). Anyways, if I were you I'd wait for a sale because it's a little overpriced but go ahead and buy it for sure. You probably won't play it a ton but it's something fun to have in your library for a rainy day.

review: Malissimo, comparado con otras entregas de Trials esta ha perdido todo su encanto, conducci√≥n torpe, donde al parecer solo hay 3 "estados" (que no se retraen de vuelta como en otras entregas, darle con el stick dependiendo del tiempo girabas mas o menos, aqu√≠ directamente tocas un milisegundo para balancear para delante o atr√°s y se queda con este balance hasta que no vuelves a tocar el stick en direcci√≥n contraria), por lo que al final en vez de tomar riendas de la destreza tienes que estar dandole a izquierda o derecha como loco, no lo recomendar√≠a ni con la rebaja del -70%, y mucho menos con el precio original...

author: {'steamid': '76561197986444501', 'num_games_owned': 1202, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1543209117}
review: I can't tell you much about the game because it's very difficult to play. It has the arbitrary uplay service (might as well buy it there instead, so you don't have TWO DRM platforms working at the same time) which will kick you out of game if you so much as cough and it can't make love to the Ubisoft servers all day and all night. The load times are fairly insane for a 2.5D game. Definitely worse than anything else except FarCry and other similar graphically intense games. The game is also very finicky (and crashy) about screen resolutions. All in all it just wasn't worth the hassle. Two thumbs down - pick it up on a console where uplay / steam and screen resolutions aren't an issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044178351', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1556506989}

author: {'steamid': '76561198046084588', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1659130186}
review:
I don't understand how this game has "Mixed" reviews -- it's fantastic. Yeah, the customization is lackluster and there are cosmetic microtransactions but who the heck plays Trials as a dress-up game?

If you play the game because you want challenging maps, rewarding single-player, competitive multiplayer or local party multiplayer, the game absolutely nails it on all those fronts. It's a great cheap alternative to Trials Rising while you wait for it to drop in price. Getting it on sale is a no-brainer purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110633351', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 971, 'last_played': 1688916996}

review: Not as good as Trials Evolution, (although I am heavily biased in that game's favor) but it's still Trials all the same. I'd say it's worth it, but you can't play track editor tracks that use DLC content if you don't have the DLC (but the DLC isn't that bad) and also cosmetic microtransactions, but it's still pure Trials fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109900464', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1552672025}
review: This game is a total blast. It has quick campaign that takes about just 4 hours to beat, but if you wanted to 100% this there is probably 10-20 more so hours of challenges. 3 challenges a level and if you're a completionist, this game is for you. The game itself is very fun, and semi difficult. It paces at a good rate in challenge, and is very fun. There's a little customization too, and if you have friends racing with them is a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038146007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 1285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 776, 'last_played': 1708924292}
review: It's an absolute joy to play! The easy levels are incredibly easy, the medium just easy, the hard actually pretty hard, and the extreme all but impossible. It's amazing how much the difficulty varies from track to track, and I love it. The minute you think you know what you're doing is the minute you spend 10 minutes trying to get past one extreme section. It gets very very hard. And it's awesome. In my 13 hours of play I've done about 60% of the tracks (including all DLC) so there is a lot of your bang for your buck here. What it comes down to is it's just downright fun, and that's why you should pick it up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198149144314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1543774249}
review:
Level design is focused on making it look good and exciting, the gameplay suffers from this. Random objects flying in and changing the track zzzzz. The levels are also wayyy too easy it actually makes you sleep.

It takes way too long to unlock all bikes and you will have to replay the whole game to gain platinum in all tracks because of this. The trick system is something that never shouldve been implemented in trials, its so bad lol and doesnt fit the game at all. 

For single player get Trials Evolution, its so much better. But if you want multiplayer I guess this is the only trials game atm with one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198415531328', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1623638266}
review:
Trials Evolution difficulty curve: Beginner -> Easy -> Medium -> Hard -> Extreme
Trials Fusion difficulty curve: Beginner -> Beginner -> Easy -> Easy -> Impossible

Seriously, the level design in this game SUCKS. Getting gold medals in anything before "Extreme" levels takes 8-10 tries max. Then in Extreme, it takes 20-30 tries to make at least 1-2 of the jumps in each track. There's just no middle ground to get you acclimated to the ridiculous difficulty in the late tracks. The mechanics are almost identical to Evolution (a bit less tight in my opinion) but Evolution is one of my favorite games ever, and I have pretty much no desire to finish this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059614369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 7704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7440, 'last_played': 1633795664}
review:
Firstly, most of the single player tracks are creative and well made (both dev and community). I quite like the futuristic setting and the way it implements a minimal story. The music, art and graphics all go well with it. It's easy to pick up and hard to master. The difficulty curve is pretty decent but then ramps up as you get to the extremes. The skill games are better than in the previous games. Some are just okay, others are fun and a lot of them teach you useful skills that will make you better and more comfortable with the bikes. I would also say this is the most difficult Trials thus far, though the bikes feel and control better. For the most part Fusion has the best customization in the series but with one caveat (that I'll get to later). 

Sadly Fusion does try to add some things to the series and it doesn't all work. It goes without saying that the FMX mode is just so finnicky to control and it isn't what the series is known for. They also added a few extra vehicles that are essentially pointless. The quad just has a few tracks of its own but it isn't part of the progression where you go from using the low end bike to the one that requires a lot of skill to master. The unicorn is just awkward to control and just doesn't have a place or a good reason to be be in the game. So that caveat about the customization is that to buy most of it (most of the better stuff) is for a microtransaction currency. You can earn some of it through tournaments and multiplayer, but as far as I know multiplayer is now dead. It is just cosmetic, but shitty nonetheless. Performance wise there have been some occassional frame drops, but mostly it's ran fine for me (using W10).

In conclusion I think Fusion is a good, worthy addition to the series. There's lots of replayability when you include DLC and the thousands of custom made tracks that are available. Maybe not quite as good as HD or Evo but it's addictive and has brought me back countless times trying to get better by beating my previous scores/other players scores on the leaderboard and just trying to pass extreme tracks I didn't think possible. For me that's the core of Trials, along with the bike and rider physics that make it a unique experience. My recommendation would be to play HD and Evo first, but either way I still recommend Fusion, (though it might be wise to consider trying the demo and buying it on sale).

author: {'steamid': '76561198081860215', 'num_games_owned': 1638, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1535113407}
review:
This feels like both a proper sequel and a bit of a backstep from Trails Evolution. The presentation is nicer looking. The tracks are a little more inventive, engaging and extreme than Trials Evolution. But the controls felt more precise on Trials Evolution.
You can buy in-game currency (golden acorns?) with real money in the typical Ubisoft tradition to purchase outfits and different bike designs that have no effect on gameplay. Some of them can be bought with coins you earn for progressing in the game. The amount of bikes to unlock was very disappointing and the way in which you unlock them felt like a missed opportunity. You could have double the bikes and made the progression feel stronger.
I've had no issues with uPlay. I already had an account with uPlay before I bought this and I am not sure if this feature is new but the only prompt I got when I ran this game was, "Do you want to add this game to your uPlay library?" I ticked yes and it has just automatically worked.
I've also experienced no crashing on an NVidia GTX970.
This review is for The Awesome MAX Edition. And I picked it up for $13 during the Summer Sale and at that price point - it was definitely worth it. However, at it's current price of $46.65 it very much is not. It's still an enjoyable game and I look forward to Trials Rising when it comes out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198381914381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1529083527}
review:
Pretty fun game, though the controls can be very clunky and overly sensitive (at least if you're using a keyboard, not sure about how well controllers work)
If you're looking for a fun yet challenging game, this is a pretty good place. The singleplayer campaign does a nice job of gradually improving your skills, although the multiplayer community seems pretty dead and rather small, which is a shame. However, you can still access maps made by other players, so you still have a lot of options when you've completeed the campaign (or if you haven't and just want to try some player made maps)
My only complaint is that part of the BMX training is just pure luck. After several atttempts I only passed the third trick by randomly mashing buttons, while the other tricks were very easy to preform once you understand how the tricks work, There aren't very many fantastic guides on how to accomplish this third trick either, it seems like many other people had the same experience as I did in that sense.
Over all, the game is very fun once you can get past the obstacles mentioned in this review, and I would recommend it UNLESS you think the obstacles are too great.
Haven't played the DLCs, so I can't say anything about them, but if you are an achievement hunter you will need them to get several achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075417920', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1690497290}
review:
WELCOME TO THE FUTURE!

TL;DR

Trials Fusion is worthy of its title and your money. You're getting a lot of bang for your buck. A lot of variety and fun. Just when you think you've run out of things to do, trust me, there's more. It takes the best qualities of Trials Evolutioon and adds to it. The micro-transactions are shitty and part of the AAA Game Dev disease, but there are still cool rider/bike combos you can have without spending extra. The learning curve is smooth, and unless you have short-term memory loss, you will carry your new skills to new and more challenging tracks and you get the satasfaction of seeing yourself beat that track you spent 10 minutes trying to complete. I recommend the Awesome Max edition, though. It doubles the playtime and they give you exclusive items as a result.

-------------

>>[SKIP THIS PARAGRAPH IF YOU DON'T WANT BACKSTRY] To start off, I want to outline my perspective on this game. A year ago, I played Trials Evolution on my friends XBOX 360. Me, being a motorcycle enthusiast and rider (as my icon insists), I found the accuracy of balance, weight shifting, suspension rebound, and throttle control enamouring. When I got the MSI I'm currently using, I was sure to buy Trials Evolution. I'm not sure if I'm just good at the game, or if my IRL riding experience helped me with my understanding of how riding motorcycles work, but I quickly made it through the game. Only slowing to a hault after getting gold on one of the Flatliner tracks and never getting more than a bronze on the two following tracks. Sometimes, games get too difficult to be fun. So I needed more hard tracks that were challenging, but manageable. So I bought Trials Fusion.<<

------------

Trials Fusion has the same rider/bike feel as its predecessor, Evolution. A refreshing new theme and graphical renaissance, I was pleased. First starting up this game is a treat on its own. The soundtrack is not only good, but it fits the theme perfectly.  I was easily bored with the beginner and easy levels, as the skill required to get gold medals on them is minimal. The tutorials were insulting to a veteran like me, but I had to do them. The medium levels keep things interesting and the hard levels are certainly worthy of their title and worthy of my time.

------------

So, what does Trials Fusion do differently? Is this just a re-skin? The answer is no, it is not. It's just as expansive and the mechanics are familiar, and the additions are pleasing. I will list them in bullet point.

> Dynamic Tracks
> Narration
> A semblance of a backstory to the theme.
> New Mode, FMX
> Three challenges per track

The Tracks are far more dynamic than Evolution. The tracks with shift, collapse, and launch you higher than giraffe- uh, probably can't say that here. It keeps things interesting. It gives you something new to learn but it can also be disorienting, causing you to crash.

Narration, now that's something unexpected. But it does make the game feel less lonely. It's nothing game-changing, it's just nice.

When you finish a track and watch the ending sequences, they are certainly more interesting than the ones in evolution. there is also a some sort of visual plot if you pay enough attention.

Oh boy, the FMX tracks. These are annoying to me. Basically, to earn medals, you have to do a bunch of tricks while airborn. That's it. It's not challenging, it's just tedious.

Challenges! These, I like. Though sometimes tough to discern how to complete the challenges, it increases playtime positively. Lets you go back and play tracks with a new perspective. I can't say much about them because I haven't done any of them yet, but once I've got gold on everything, I'll be sure to go back and play it all over.

The theme is nice. But it feels colder that evolution. Trials Evolution had a hazy and cozy rustic theme that reminds me of my hometown, and I really enjoyed it. This is personally preferrential, and shouldn't be considered if you're thinking about buying this game.

---------------

Now, what don't I like about Trials fusion? Que the bullet list!

> Micro-transactions
> limited rider and bike customization
> FMX 
> You can't use every bike on every track.

Oh, Ubisoft. You fell to greed once again. Of all the games, why Trials Fusion? There are bike "body kits," wheels, and rider clothing that you can only get by buying "Acorns," an in-game currency that costs you IRL money. It's just sad.

Trials Evolution let you edit every single detail of your machine and rider. It was wonderful. So many items to choose from and so many colors to pick! Wanna change your front fender design? Do it. Wanna put hand guards on your Pihrana 450? Do it! Wanna mix and match your rider? Well, you can do it! Trials fusion? No. You get your choice of mildly differentiating clothing sets that you unlock at certain levels. Some of them, you change the colors, some you cannot. No gloves, no boots, no goggle color change relative to the helmet. It's just not there. Same with the bikes. Sure, you have more wheel and body kit options, but they're all changed large-scale. It's limiting and I don't like it.

I like the Foxbat. It reminds me of the Pihrana 450. But you can only use it on FMX tracks. If you bought the Awesome Max edition, you get a unicorn. Which you can only use on special tracks. you can use the pit viper, quad, baggie, pitbike, and roach on every track, but not the foxbat or unicorn. :c

Verdict:
Trials Fusion is worthy of its title and your money. you're getting a lot of bang for your buck. A lot of variety and fun. Just when you think you've run out of things to do, trust me, there's more. It takes the best qualities of Trials Evolutioon and adds to it. The micro-transactions are shitty and part of the AAA Game Dev disease, but there are still cool rider/bike combos you can have without spending extra. The learning curve is smooth, and unless you have short-term memory loss, you will carry your new skills to new and more challenging tracks and you get the satasfaction of seeing yourself beat that track you spent 10 minutes trying to complete. I recommend the Awesome Max edition, though. It doubels the playtime and they give you exclusive items as a result.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063115240', 'num_games_owned': 2828, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1499, 'last_played': 1508071714}
review:
[h1] This is the best Trials game in my opinion. [/h1]

[b] Unfortunately the Season Pass doesn't include Awesome Level MAX Edition content, you'd have to buy both of these to enjoy the game to the fullest. [/b]

What makes this game different is the community created levels. There are a lot of levels created by the players and you can create them too then share it. However, if you  don't buy all of the game's content, then it's pretty much useless. Most, if not all, of the community created levels are made using DLCs, so if you don't own that particular DLC, you won't be able to play it. Another thing worth mentioning is that some of the community members enjoy trolling which can result in weird and near-impossible levels to complete.

The graphics are great and the textures are quite realistic even now. Soundtrack is awesome and fits in with the game and its levels perfectly. Game-play is slightly different from the previous game, it's a bit harder. Few later levels could seem impossible to complete if you're not using a controller. You can perform different kinds of tricks with your bike and rider, you can customize almost every single thing in the game and there are tons of customization options!

[b] [i] I would be happy to recommend this game to any Trials fan. [/i] [/b]

review:
Great game overall.
The physics feel very accurate, but be warned: The difficulty in the later stages of the game increase immensely and only few will be able to finish those without putting effort into understanding how to control your bike and build up muscle memory. 
In the early stages however it is casual and even as an experienced player you can still have almost zen-like fun with this.
There is just something satisfying about landing smoothly into an arc at high speeds.
Always having fun when I come back to this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060686749', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1521835031}
review:
Try the demo first, especially if you play with keyboard.

Maybe it's easy with sticks, but with keyboard it seems to be next to impossible, at least when you get to the FMX tricks where they don't really explain anything, just show you a few pictures and expect you to figure out how to do them.

It looks like a nice game, and it was fun at first, even if the bike reacts far too quick and strong for my taste. That I could explain with me being bad at this game.
But once I got to the FMX wind tunnel and spent 10 minutes looking for answers about how to do these tricks, I simply gave up. No game is worth the headache you'll get trying to figure out just what the game wants from you.
(If they'd at least put the NAME of the trick they want you to do somewhere, then it'd be easier to look it up. Not everyone is a stunt expert.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062070763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1518869041}
review:
This game doesn't always work with Windows 10. It gets to the menu screen, then crashes - every time. Theer is no working solution online, at Uplay. This problem had existed for some time, apparently, and Steaamshould have been some sort of warning for potential buyers, especially people running Windows 10.

I boutgh this on sale, for $5.99, and it wasn't worth that. If I want to play it on a console, I'll have to pay $20. I would hate to give my money to a company that won't optimize its game for the systems they sell it on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110856032', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1739, 'last_played': 1539447379}
review: I had Trials Evolution for the XB360 and loved it, no different with Fusion. There's comedy in the voice acting, fun in the action, and challenge everywhere else. The progression from beginner to expert, and the training courses that are in between, makes for a smooth progression that then ramps up once you're thoroughly enjoying the pain. I found it very enjoyable to also complete as many challenges as I could while going through the levels (as long as they weren't restricted by not knowing tricks yet or using a bike I didn't own of course), as well as explore the levels for secrets hidden along the way (hint: [spoiler]tons of them are behind the starting points of the courses[/spoiler]). All in all, if you liked those motocross flash games from the 2000s, any of the Trials games, or torturing your coordination until your brain and fingers beg you to stop, you'll love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210022420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1482531033}
review:
[h1][b][u]OVERALL[/u]: 6/10[/b][/h1]
  
It's a good little game, it's fun but it gets hard a bit too soon in my opinion. Once you'll reach a certain stage, you'll start pulling your hair off. I mean what good comes out of trying to climb up a fucking pipe a hundred times over ?!?!?! I ONLY RECOMMEND BUYING ON A GOOD SALE.


[h1][b][u]GAMEPLAY[/u]: 5.5/10[/b][/h1]

Decent gameplay yet very frustrating because it is really sensitive, trying not to lean too much foreward or backward becomes hellish in late game. Not to mention checkpoints that ruin your momentum and actually make the course harder to complete. On the flipside, getting a perfect course making all the right moves has a real good feel.

[h1][b][u]LEVEL DESIGN[/u]: 7/10[/b][/h1]

This is trial bike so the opportunity to make crazy levels is there, and there sure is crazy levels. The game did a great job with the design of the courses, only the unforgiving difficulty of later stages drops the score. This is Trial Fusion's best aspect.

[h1][b][u]VISUAL & ART[/u]: 5.5/10[/b][/h1]

Good yet not great. Nothing particular to point out, decent stuff.

[h1][b][u]SOUND & MUSIC[/u]: 4/10[/b][/h1]

Annoying musics and the sound of your bike accelerating over that same damned obstacle drives me nuts ! Sound design is pretty poor.

[h1][b][u]REPLAYABILITY[/u]: 6.5/10[/b][/h1]

It all depends on your frustration / skill level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043974607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1517591673}
review:
Pas mal du tout, dans la lign√©e des trials pr√©c√©dents (impitoyable apr√®s le d√©but en douceur) mais en infiniment plus beau. On en profite limite pas vu le niveau de concentration requis, mais la r√©alisation et les mouvements de cam√©ra en mettent bien plein la gueule. Mention sp√©ciale pour l'humour, les textes et dialogues d√©biles enregistr√©s sont parfois vraiment dr√¥les (m√™me s'ils rippent parfois un tout petit peu trop l'esprit Portal).
Mais...

Mais c'est un jeu Ubi, ce qui veut dire :
- interface hideuse et lourdingue, chargements √† tous les niveaux, du coup √ßa prend des plombes pour naviguer
- acc√®s intempestifs aux serveurs d'ubi m√™me en solo qui font lagguer encore un peu plus l'interface d√©j√† asthmatique
- trouze monnaies (inutiles) in game qui sentent bon l'hame√ßon √† baleine
- des objectifs, sous-objectifs, sur-objectifs, meta-objectifs et objectifs vrill√©s-carp√©s, tous subdivis√©s en niveaux de r√©ussite, remultipli√©s par les addons, bref des trucs de partout que si on veut tout faire, que on est oblig√© d'y passer 18 ans (spoiler : aucun int√©r√™t si ce n'est l'onanisme compar√© pour les compl√©tionistes qui ont trop de temps)
- des crash r√©guliers dans les menus (ben ouais, trop lourds, trop de trucs, trop de shaders, de loadings asynchrones et d'acc√®s r√©seau, ubi => √ßa crashe)
- et √©videmment Uplaie (purrulente) √† se supporter...

Voil√† voil√†, √ßa reste fun si c'est pas cher, mais pour moi c'est "next" maintenant.

review: I have always loved the Trials Games all the way back to Trials HD on the Xbox 360 and when I saw this was on PC I immeditately bought this game along with all the DLC.  It is definitely well worth your money and the custom maps add tons more hours of playtime as well as the DLC.  However, if you're looking to play this game for the multiplayer or with friends, I would not recommend it because the multiplayer is fairly dead.  Other than that I would highly recommend.

review: The mechanics of the game are really simple.  The skill level of the game ramps up from easy to impossible.  Don't watch others play, they make it look easy.  Trouble is, you end up returning over and over to see if you can improve on your score.  An old game, but with incredible longevity.  Has been a favourite for years, and will be for years to come.  Just buy it!

review: I've only grazed the game. But from a previous stand point of the trials games. It just makes me laugh, and its fun. Its a platformer kind of game. This one is more wacky then the last. The screams and joy youre rider is having is seriously what makes me enjoy it. I like that there going straight out into a random weird world direction it gives the game endless possibilites. I hope ubisoft continues this line of games because there isnt anything out there like this. I wish more developers would create these types of games. Reminds me almost of that ball puzzle PC game that came out almost two decades ago. But i like this game. And every reviewer stating Uplay, Uplay, Uplay. I guess logging onto steam was really hard. Uplay works, and its not going anywhere. Game runs flawless on my machine and quite detailed though i think it could use more graphic intensity. Although its quite a lot of maps if you really think about it. Game has a lot. And best part is i always leave with a big grin on my face after playing it. And now thats the right kind of game if you ask me.

This Game will have u see a visible improvement of ur skill even after 500h of Gametime. author: {'steamid': '76561198112219396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1555247211}
review:
I've watched a lot of Trials Fusion videos but never really thought about buying it myself but finally i did and i'm just loving it.
Been playing this game daily and slowly learning and improving. Sure it gets pretty stressful to the point where i came so close to smashing my controller...
But it's a very addictive game, the visuals looks great, controls takes time to get use to. 
I'm just enjoying the learning process and actually trying to be at least decent at this game and not totally suck at it. 
Got it for $9 Great deal for sure. Try it only if you know what you're getting yourself into~
Definitely not a game for everybody

review:
Tr√®s bon jeu, tr√®s fun qui demande du skill.

Le jeu est tr√®s complet, certaines pistes sont plus difficiles que d'autres. Le challenge est au rendez-vous.

Graphiquement, le titre est plut√¥t joli, de jolis effets de lumi√®re, les musiques sont bonnes aussi, le bruitage des motos n'est pas toujours tr√®s r√©aliste, mais bon le jeu en lui m√™me n'est pas r√©aliste donc on lui pardonne. L'optimisation du jeu est bonne √©galement. Le gameplay reste le m√™me que les opus pr√©c√©dents, et c'est tr√®s bien comme √ßa.

En conclusion, voila un bon d√©fouloir en terme de jeu de moto, perso quand on s'ennuie chez soi c'est le top, et ce type de jeu convient parfaitement.

18/20

review: Man muss sich ein bisschen Zeit geben um die Mechanik und das Timing zu lernen (vom meistern bin ich noch weit entfernt...). Aber dann ist es immer wieder befriedigend eine Strecke nach hunderten Versuchen endlich geschafft zu haben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279204238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1696994922}
review:
I'm completely new to this kind of game, and if you are as well, then know that this one is generally considered the best - at the very least in the "Trials" series. Apparently later installments aren't as good.

It's a fun game. It's almost like a modernized version of Excite Bike, although in career mode, you're not racing against others. The challenge level is just right, I think. Whenever I'd start off a new section, it seemed tough as nails, but it doesn't take too many tries to get good enough to pass a course.

There's also level-building and a community of user-made levels to play, which is very fun. However, many of these will be locked out to you if you don't have the DLCs.
