author: {'steamid': '76561198069884248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1490243062}
review:
Trials Fusion is the latest installment in what has generally been a game that offers a simple premise but provides a lot of gameplay punch.  While there aspects of Fusion that I am greatly impressed with, there are a few things that I am unhappy with. 

For those unfamiliar, the Trials games are a very simple premise. You're riding a motorbike (along with other vehicles in Fusion) across a large variety of tracks with physics being the ultimate gameplay component. You have to control the bike properly or you will wipe out.....A LOT!

I've broken this into a simple pros/cons list for anyone that has tl;dr issues :-)

Pros:
+ Looks fantastic. The colors are rich and have real pop to them. If you can play this in Ultra at the highest resolution you're in for a treat, even at lower resolutions it still is great eye candy
+ Base game course design is interesting for the most part and the futuristic setting adds more than I thought it would.
+ Trick/FX gameplay styles really add to the depth and encourage playing tracks multiple times with both fastest times and trick scores being seperate goals.
+ A ton of community made tracks at your fingertips.

Cons:
- Pricey DLC with the season pass costing the same price as the base game making MSRP for both base and season pass (a.k.a. Deluxe Edition) just $20 less than a AAA title. There have been two DLC packs released thus far with more to come.
- Some base game courses are much shorter than you'd expect.
- Lacks the challenge at the lower levels that earlier Trials titles brought. Seems watered down for casuals/newcomers in respects. The physics are still brutal depending on course, but definitely easier to get the hang of. ATVs are disgustingly easy.
-  Four months after release and online multiplayer is still not in the game, yet is promised by the developer. This is UNACCEPTABLE when being advertised as having multiplayer especially at the cost of the full package. Local multiplayer only at the moment (8/23/14 is the date of this review).
- Tedious unlocking system.
- There seems to be some measure of a "story" mode to the single player game where you're regularly spoken to by a female AI similar to GlaDOS of the Portal games, except the Trials AI lady lacks the wit of that classic character and is generally just grating.

Let me be clear, while my cons are glaring, I do not regret my purchase of this game. I have a real soft spot for this series and have gotten a lot of mileage out of the earlier titles and am going to continue to play this one as it plays well and I can't overstate how great it looks. I was first introduced to Trials when it came out on Xbox 360 Arcade and I put well over 100 hours into that iteration of the game. I hesitated on this new one until I upgraded my hardware and now that I have, I am very glad I waited at least until then.  That being said, unless you are like me and a fan of the Trials series and know what you're getting into, do yourself a favor and hold off until this is on sale. 

I recommend this with a caveat. Definitely pick it up when on sale, but unless you're really into the series/gameplay style, you're fine waiting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047626849', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3086, 'last_played': 1553235337}
review:
You can lose numerous hours playing and hunting times in this great game! You will also rage but it isn‚Äôt like most games because of the game mechanics it‚Äôs because of your ability, but this makes you strive for a better time and keeps you coming back to Trials Fusion.

All impressive maps design, graphics Easter Eggs (Squirrels) bikes and customization and also challenges have been done brilliantly. Also after you have completed the campaign to your ability you can get stuck into user created tracks which further makes the game playable.

The new addition to Trials Fusion which include the new FMX trick system is great too!

Only a few minor downsides for me.. The voice/screaming of character gets quite annoying after a while although you can turn it off and the extreme track Inferno IV. That damn map! 
And obviously the biggest downside is Uplay!

One recommendation which i would give is that you should use a controller as it is easier to control your bike.

In summary this is a great game which you can easily rage but get addicted to. Ubisoft needs to stop using UPlay for future titles.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198099961139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1442688774}
review: I want to start off with the good parts of this game. I played the previous Trials games on the console and I was hoping that I could continue the series on PC. To an extent, I did. The gameplay was as I remember, i.e., incredibly addicting and rewarding. If you were to compare stills of this game to the previous games, you could tell it looks incredibly better. But after I got past the introductory phase, I started realising how annoying logging into Uplay was. I also ran into frame rate problems. I'm not implying that I'm running a powerful system (my graphics card being a Radeon HD 7870), but compared to the smooth 60 fps I can maintain on medium settings in Metro: Last Light and Bioshock Infinity, I found the 40 fps and often 20 fps on low settings to be COMPLETELY absurd. I'm quite offended that the developers put less care to the PC version but I suppose it's my fault for assuming otherwise from Ubisoft. Although I do enjoy playing the game on occasion, I cannot recommend it to anyone without a more powerful system. The low fps is more than nauseating as usual but actually disruptive in the gameplay. Please play the demo, which I'm very grateful is provided, before thinking of purchasing it; something I was too anxious to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960959866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1456915398}
review:
I bought this because I wanted a fun multiplayer game to play with my friends. After paying full price for the game, I download it only to discover it has local multiplayer only. Talk about misleading.

Totally dissapointed. If only steam offered exchange / refunds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009704277', 'num_games_owned': 607, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1437766866}
review: I'd love to hate this game, but I simply can't. As the matter of fact - I love it. At least the first 30 minutes of each gameplay session, until frustration takes the best of me. Unlike other titles, where frustration comes from bad gameplay mechanics, clunky controls or just plain bugs - this game has none of those. Frustration comes only from your own mistakes and lack of focus and patience. I had no problem with the BEGINNER and EASY difficulty mode tracks, whereas in MEDIUM, I first took the time to learn the track and adapt to the ever-changing layout. HARD is where things got really painful. Let's just say that I had to repeat one track a hundred times to get the gold medal. Frustration was followed by a great sense of achievement. I find the new FMX trick system fun, but very difficult or just needed to get used to. One more problem, mentioned by most Steam users: Uplay. Being forced to use two types of DRM is ridiculous and Uplay sucks in general. Sometimes it takes ages to load certain data (bikes, rider accessories and the list of tracks) from the cloud. I bought this game mainly for the purpose of local co-op so I was devastated to find out that you weren't able to play the user-created tracks with your friends. After the latest patch they finally implemented that feature so hopefully we'll have more than the default 10 tracks to enjoy. To sum things up, I enjoy most of the features of Trials: Fusion. Just two things need to go: my lack of skill and Uplay. 9/10

review:
I approve of this game.

The visuals are good, the gameplay feels grippy and responsive and is quite easy for even new players to get into.
The music and sound in this game is well done, creative narrating voice that follows you along the many tracks of the game.

The only downside of this is that there is no online multiplayer yet, but it will come eventually so until then I would recommend this game to anyone who loves to show off their skill or who love to see their biker slam their head against several concrete walls!

review: If you like Trials for the multiplayer, this is easily the worst. After months of no custom multiplayer maps, now there are around 10-20 available to download, to add to the 12-odd which come with the game. In all, you can play them in an afternoon, if that. Aside from this, the game has no real improvements from Evolution. If you want Trials, get that instead. Cheaper and more maps, without being any different graphically.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018651108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1407448423}
review:
This is the first Trials game I've played and I'm really enjoying it with the exception of two things.
1: Lags all the time for no good reason. The internet's only solution is to decrease the resolution, but I'm at the minimum res and it's still doing it.
2: Why isn't there a female rider? It's 2014, why can't I play as a girl in a motocross game? I could play as a girl in the freaking PS2's ATV Offroad Fury 2 and that came out in the early 2000s. There's literally no reason to not have a female body option.

Game itself is gorgeous and fun and, provided the lag holds off or is somehow solvable, I'll be playing a lot of this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094147140', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1403857205}
review:
NOTE: This is a long, detailed review. Longness may occur past this point.

I had never played a Trials game before, but was familiar with the series, so I bought Fusion before the Summer Sale ended. I figured I'd be playing it a lot over the summer and as a general timewaster, so I bought the Season Pass with it, for a total of $30.

Honestly, I feel like I've wasted my money buying this game.

Having never played any other Trials games, I have nothing to compare the gameplay of Fusion against. I do know that it has no online multiplayer, which is a major disappointment. Looking through other reviews, I can see that the game is apparently lacking in other places (lack of tracks, buggy trick system, etc.), but again, I have nothing to compare it against, so I can't verify these claims. In my 2 hours of playing, the core gameplay has been solid. However, it's been mostly unenjoyable, which brings me to my first major quip with this game:

[b]1. The game is horribly optimized[/b]

I started up my game to my rider rising up an elevator in the first tutorial level. It was going pretty slowly, maybe for dramatic effect. And then the slowness carried on through the level. and the next one after that. What was the problem behind this? [b]It turns out Trials Fusion is hellbent on running at 60 FPS. If you can't run it at 60 FPS, the game merely slows itself down until every in-game second has 60 frames.[/b] The result? If you run it at 40 FPS, every 3 real-life seconds becomes 2 seconds in-game. 30 FPS? Your game runs at half-speed. 20 FPS? A minute-long tracks now takes 3 minutes to complete. [b]Have you ever put an old game in your floppy disc drive of your computer and it runs at lightning speed because the game speed was tied to processor speed? Trials Fusion goes 15 years into the past to bring back this experience.[/b] And don't you worry, they thought of that one supercomputer that can run the game at 90 FPS, so the game caps at 60 FPS so it doesn't run away.

All in all, after crippling the resolution, video settings, and everything else, the game ran at an average of 45 FPS for me, where it started off at 15. My GPU may not be the greatest in the world (AMD Radeon HD 7640G), but it gets the job done for every other game I've played at decently high settings. Trials Fusion at its lowest possible settings [i]still[/i] brings my GPU to its knees.

[b]2. uPlay is a piece of crap and attempted to eat my computer[/b]

A little backstory here. I bought Burnout Paradise during the 2013 Summer Sale. Upon launching, EA promted me to make on Origin account, which I did. They didn't bug me any further, and from then on, Burnout launched through Steam and my Origin log-in was confirmed after launching.

So why is it that Trials Fusion requires you to install uPlay, and that launching Trials from Steam [i]only launches uPlay?[/i] If I only had to make a uPlay account to play (like with Burnout!), it would be fine. But why do I need a [i]second[/i] game-launcher just to accomplish the task of launching my game, Ubisoft? So launching Trials Fusion is clumsy and weird because it requires installing uPlay, which seems bad enough. For me, however, it was the start of my problems.

A couple of days after installing TF, Flash videos stopped working, which required me to disable hardware acceleration to fix. Whatever, Flash is buggy anyway. And then weird black bars appeared near the top of the window when I was watching a Twitch stream. OK, maybe something is wrong here, so I'll run an antivirus scan. My computer crashed mid-scan, and then I got my first blue screen the next day. The day after that the most ominous thing of all happened. I was watching a video when it flipped to another screen that said, "You can activate your operating system under the Settings tab." I went back to the video, and minimized my screen to reveal that I could now see my OS and build in the lower-right hand corner of my desktop. At that point, I went to System Restore and got uPlay the hell out of my computer. It's been about a month since the restore, and to date, nothing nearly as spooky as the aforementioned things has happened again.

[b]SUMMARY/TL;DR:[/b]

You may notice next to the thumbs-down that I have 2 hours logged playing this game. This is due to a combination of the problems mentioned above. In my short time playing Trials Fusion, the gameplay wasn't that good for me, because it didn't run at full-speed. I can imagine it would be a great game if the damn thing would run correctly and stop being so picky. Ubisoft has done a decent job patching their errors, adding things like "better" optimization and custom Supercross tracks. Until they fix the bigger things though, I can't say anything good about this game. In conclusion...

-Only get this game if you're absolutely confident in your computer's specs, ESPECIALLY GPU
-Don't expect online play anytime soon (because the poor slow-motion guy would be left behind...)
-uPlay is a piece of crap
-If your computer fights back after installing uPlay, you should listen to it
-#4spooky
-I like donuts :3

author: {'steamid': '76561197995330335', 'num_games_owned': 1096, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1468749203}
review:
This is not a terrible game by any means, but it feels like a definite step back from the previous installment and, by comparison especially, a lousy value proposition.

The tracks are significantly fewer and blander, and that's not balanced out by the new mechanisms.

Doing tricks seems to be based on your angle and the input on the right stick, but it feels pretty sketchy/inconsistent. The stages built around doing those tricks for points are too unforgiving: the checkpointing means you only get one shot at each jump trick, so any failed attempt means you've lost a potential 20% or so points for that stage. Maybe losing your multiplier would have been enough of a deterrent; as it stands, falling is too easy and too costly, so it makes sense to play it safe -- and that's boring, especially for a mode that's supposed to be a bit more crazy than the precision driving at the core of the franchise. Uniracers did it first and better, basically.

'Challenges' are either Easter eggs hard to figure out without a guide, or require feats like finishing with zero fault while doing 10 tricks or never letting go of the gas pedal. That's one way to stretch playtime over a small number of tracks...

Tournaments are one thing that's improved, though: they're time-limited and renewed every few hours, which is a good encouragement to participate and try to rank high.

Now that the first piece of DLC (out of a planned 6) is out, it's obvious that we can't count on them to fix the fundamental problem of there not being enough content: each will be the size of a world, so 6 regular tracks and 2 gimmicky ones (and the first pack is boring like the rest, too).

Are RedLynx / Ubi counting on player-created content to pick up the slack? Trying to find really good content is still a crapshoot though -- you can only rely on the 'featured' categories, very basic filters, or a percentage of positive reviews. There's quite a few enjoyable enough tracks, some with clever moments, but few if any are comparable in quality to the dev-made tracks from Trials Evolution, and you have to be in the mood to rummage around for them.

It pains me to say it, but this is a disappointment. Just get Trials Evolution, and don't get Fusion until you've played so much Evo you're sick of it. And even then, be aware it's not great value at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089875941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1405633162}
review:
Estoy muy descontento con este juego.
Primero, es solo para Uplay, cosa que no es muy molesta pero que no es buena. Despues esta el tema de que esta lleno de bugs, pero cuando digo lleno, es que en cada pista te encuentras 1 o 2. Unicamente tiene multijugador local, cosa que no pasaba en las anteriores entregas, y es un verdadero fallo. En mi opinion es demasiado caro para lo que es, pero es solo una opinion. Pero lo que mas me molesta, es que mi PC cumpla los requisitos recomendados mas que de sobra, pero que incluso con todo al minimo no funcione bien (que porcierto, al tener pocos FPS el juego se pone en camara lenta automaticamente, cosa que lo hace injugable)
En resumen, le doy un 4/10 y estoy siendo generoso.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995532620', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1439754126}
review:
It's Trials.

In spite of requiring Uplay to run, and regardless of what you think of Ubisoft as a publisher, it's still Trials. That alone is enough for me to recommend it.

Aside from the future motif, what's new from previous games is a trick system with some freestyle events to go along with it. I found the system to be really finicky, and most of the time I just skipped the FMX events in favor of the standard trials events. Also, they added a quadbike along with its own separate tier of events, which I enjoyed riding. It's 4WD and heavier than the RWD bikes we're used to.

Also, apart from the usual replayability from the medals and leaderboards, there are also different challenges for each trials track. Some of them are skill-based (e.g. flipping, riding without leaning, etc.), some involve manipulating the environment, and some are just funny or gimmicky. However, many of them are quite difficult to figure out, and the squirrels from Evolution return as well. Also making a return is the track editor, which allows you to create, share, and ride user-made tracks.

And then if you feel like enough of a badass, there are the ninja stages, which just make me want to cry...

author: {'steamid': '76561198090018488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1528843769}
review: Honestly, this games has a lot of good things about it, the graphics are a huge improvement over its predecessor and the physics seem a lot more accurate. I could sing its praises all day. However, there are a few things which pull it down. Generally I would say the soundtrack of fusion is a lot worse than that of evolution. it has it's positives but it really couldn't get me as psyched as evolutions. Also, it feels easier. The falls are softer and the bikes are easier to handle. Some would say that's a good thing but i really don't think it is. trials is like dark souls, a game to tear your hair out at. Whereas this I breezed through until the extreme levels. Overall I'd really recommend this game, but maybe not for ¬£16. Under a tenner would be an amazing price however.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003378041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1489346661}
review:
Trials Fusion apporte une nouvelle ambiance futuriste √† une saga incontournable, qui sans surprendre se voit ici am√©lior√©e par quelques petites nouveaut√©s. Un certain sentiment de stagnation peut se faire sentir apr√®s l'excellent deuxi√®me opus, mais Trials Fusion reste un bonheur unique qui ne se refuse pas, avec comme toujours un gameplay r√©gl√© aux petits oignons, un moteur physique exigeant, du contenu √† gogo, ce fameux sentiment de progression constante et cette comp√©tition permanente qui d√©livre tant de fun... Bref, un troisi√®me opus pas franchement surprenant, mais qui reste une valeur s√ªre

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Trials Fusion brings a new futuristic atmosphere a must saga, which sees no surprise here enhanced by a few novelties. A sense of stagnation can be felt after the excellent second album, but Trials Fusion remains a unique happiness that can not be refused, as always with gameplay set with onions, requiring a physics engine, content galore, this famous feeling of constant progression and this constant competition that delivers so much fun ... in short, a third installment not really surprising, but still a safe bet

author: {'steamid': '76561198040597245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1405983335}
review:
I feel like you have to know what Trials is before you play it. If you don't, you might be very surprised after playing it for a bit. The first set of levels are simple and enjoyable. The middle ones are pretty tough. The final tracks will frustrate the hell out of you. Some tracks are normal trials, then others are stunt tracks and mini games. Most of the tracks have 3 bonus challenges, so there are reasons to go back and revisit all of them. You can also try to beat your friends times (and scores I think) on each track.

I haven't even downloaded any player created courses yet, but I know from playing Trials Evolution on Xbox 360 that people make some crazy stuff to play.

I think most people can enjoy this game. The controls are simple, but challenging to perfect in the later levels. The game provides a great challenge for people, but casual players can enjoy it too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046566765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1676755368}
review:
(Please note that I am downvoting this as a sequel if you have played previous Trials games. If you have never played a trials game before then you won't understand why i think this one is a failure so go ahead and play it.)

As a standalone game this would be amazing. I'm a big fan of the Trials series (go to hell Uplay and Ubisoft with it). However this one just doesn't stand up to the previus installments. 

It's clear ubisoft was trying to appeal to the "new generation" with all the techno bits and futuristic looking backdrops, which I guess is standard for Ubisoft nowadays isn't it? 

I really like the solid color art style in other games like portal or Mirror's Edge, but it feels kind of out of place her. That's nto to say it's completely out of place as it still works. but as a long time player I miss the gritty and harsh art style of old. Just my preference though.

*Important* If you were hoping to find those unforgetably cool tracks like the one's from Evolution and HD then you will be disappointed. The tracks leave something to be desired and I breezed through all of them fairly easily. There's no Castle Crash or Gigatrack or Archipeligo. I rememebr most if nto all the tracks from Trials HD and Evolution by simply hearing the name but i couldn't even tell you the names of th first few tracks in Fusion. This is rather big for me as I really wanted the memory hook that previous tracks had given me. 

They give each difficulty a general "Theme" for example the second area you unlock is supposed to be in the city but I couldn't be less enthusiastic about the environments. They just seem copy and pasted together and I turned off the audio because I didn't find "Cindy" or that pother guy i couldn't bother to remember the name of.

If this sounds like I'm calling Ubiusoft out on being the dirtbags they so desperately desire to be then you may be on to something there. But I still LIKE the game I'm just not in love with it like i was the previous ones, and if a sequal can't superceed it's predocessors then it's a failure as a sequel.

But I am sure we will see more of Trials as Ubisoft has made it clear that there are no such things as standalone games anymore.

Go to hell Ubisoft and takle your piece of shit excuse for a "Client" with you

Also i would be nice if steam had a spell check, I knwo that's lazy but I'm legally blind so proof reading is too much of a hassle

author: {'steamid': '76561198054293523', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1403657666}
review:
The game has a really good and fun way of playing and riding a motor bike, which makes the gameplay very good.
The levels get very hard, most gamers won't be able to finish the entire single player campaign. I don't know if I find this very fun or not, because it's good to have a challenging game but this makes it a rage game, which I don't really like. Of course you could always just not finish the single player and move on to the custom maps but most of those are very hard aswell, so you are fucked either way.

But the real problem for me, and the reason why I don't recommend it is, the local multiplayer supercross.
In the prequel (trials evo) you had 10 or so standard supercross tracks and you could download a bunch of custom ones.
In this game, you also have 10 or so standard supercross tracks but you can't download any custom supercross maps.
This makes the supercross very lame very fast and is the reason why I won't buy another trials game if they don't implement it anymore.

TLDR:
If you like a challenge and you liked the old trials evo's singleplayer maps you will really like this game.
But if you want to play with your friends, don't buy it and stay with evo.

Si te quedas estancado en los niveles m√°s dificiles siempre puedes volver a los m√°s sencillos e intentar batir los retos de tiempos, habilidad y medallas. Pr√°ctica e insistencia es el √∫nico requisito para el √©xito!

Pero no se acaba aqu√≠, cuando completas todas las pistas a√∫n hay m√°s contenido gracias a la comunidad. El contenido subido por los usuarios es muy variado y con un buen acabado, la cantidad es abundante y tendr√°s diversi√≥n durante mucho tiempo.

Realmente es uno de esos juegos en los que puedes gastar tu dinero y no arrepentirte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032856156', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1012, 'last_played': 1666236830}
review:
Trials Fusion ist f√ºr alle Gamer, die mit der Franchise bekannt sind, sofort sehr einleuchtend. Die Fahrphysik ist weitgehend gleich und die Steuerung f√ºhlt sich von Anfang an vertraut an. Die Motorr√§der sind wieder sehr verschieden, teile nsich aber fast wie in Trials Evolution auf. Auch der Multiplayer (zum Zeitpunkt des Reviews nur lokal vorhanden) bietet den selben Spa√ü, wie bei Trials Fusion.

Ge√§ndert hat sich jedoch auch etwas, so dass das Spiel mit neuen Ideen und Mechaniken √ºberzeugen kann. Zun√§chst ist da der Look und die Musik. ich pers√∂nlich mag den Umschwung von dem etwas farblosen und realistischeren Trials Evolution zu der farbenfrohen und futuristischen Welt von Trials Evolution. Die Kommentatoren sind witzig und haben einen leichten Hauch von Glados und Cave Johnson aus der Portal-Serie. Das Spiel scheint in seinem neuen Look wesentlich bessere Performance zu bieten als der Vorg√§nger, was leider f√ºr viele Spieler ein Ausschlusskriterium war.

Das Gameplay wird durch die Einf√ºhrung von Tricks im FMX-Modus und Fahrzeuge wie das Quad oder das Fahrrad (was bei Trials Evolution nicht auf dem PC verf√ºgbar war) aufgefrischt. Diese haben andere Fahreigentschaften, was zu Beginn gew√∂hnungsbed√ºrftig ist. Jede Strecke ist nun mit drei Challenges ausgestattet, welche in ihrer Schwierigkeit von einem Parkspaziergang bis hin zur Evakurierung von Hoth reichen.

Trials Fusion ist bestimmt nicht bahnbrechend und bestimmt auch kein AAA-Spiel, aber es ist durch seine simplen Mechaniken bestechend und bietet Anspron zur Verbesserung einer Zeit oder dem Erreichen neuer Medallien.

Hier noch einige kurze Bulletpoints zum Bedenken:

+ Stil und gestaltung
+ Atmosph√§re der Strecken
+ Benutzererstellte Strecken
+ Durch Medallien und Challenges gro√üe Langzeitmotivation
+ Coole Neuerungen im Gameplay
+ wesentlich bessere Performance auf ATI Grafikkarten

- Keine "bahnbrechende" Neuerungen im Gameplay
- Staffelung der Challenges stimmt oft nicht mit der Schwierigkeit der Strecke √ºberein
- Platinmedallien erst nach Kompletierung fast aller Strecken verf√ºgbar
- Teilweise sehr un√ºbersichtlicher Streckeneditor
- Tournaments schlecht erkl√§hrt
- Aktuell kein Online-Multiplayer

author: {'steamid': '76561197992171220', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1506792991}
review:
Could ahve been as fun as HD and Evolution, ala Ubisoft mingled in some of their fairy dust and I stopped playing after 1 week.

Stunt Maps are part of the global leader boards , which means it's not about beating times only any more, usually have to wait around 30 seconds after each map to sublit your new scores , because connections to uplay is always laggy. That is if your lucky and it didn't time out again. in this case you ahve to retry submitting your score if you managed to get a better time.

Multiplayer is local only, which means forget about all the fun you had with evolution playing supercross tracks, it doesn't exists in this game.

Regardless of all the uplay crap the PC version is still a mess. Duel Screen support doesn;t work like in other games, the second screen always blacks out, so you can't do anything else while waiting for your scores to submit.
Window mode would have been a solution if the game could keep up the frame rates. And that is with a 780ti. God forbid you have a less powerful GFX.

If your interested in Trial games , stick with Evolution. If you want to reward Ubisoft for realeasing unfinished crap by Fusion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064932826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1677, 'last_played': 1399329490}
review:
Trials Fusion can be summed up with a resounding "more of the same". But when "the same" is the perfectly balanced gameplay of a game like Trials Evolution, we can only rejoyce.

Trials Fusion adds to the mix a futuristic setting, a couple more vehicles and a more powerful and revamped editor (one of the staples of the series). But it's not over, with online leaderboards, multiplayer, and tons and tons of user-created tracks this game is basically eternal.

Clearly not revolutionary as Trials Evolution, you can still count on the fact that Trials Fusion will entertain you for hundreds of hours.

Remember, if don't use the fantastic editor to create at least one track and share it with your friends, you are missing out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198120609690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1736, 'last_played': 1583635857}
review: I've been a fan of Trials for some time, and I poured at least a total week into Evolution. That being said, I plan on pouring another week into this fantastic follow-up. This game has everything Evolution had and 5 times more. The stunning graphics, engaging setting and plot, FMX, and even more features in the editor are just a few of the great new things about this game. The one huge downside is the necessity of Uplay. It's really just a pain in the butt. However, the rewards and stuff along with the Trial Frontier connection kind of make up for the inconvenience. Seriously a 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086342346', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 19154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11922, 'last_played': 1656123857}
review:
After so many hours playing this game, I have found that it is still extremely fun. Not having the season pass makes the online portion of the game much less interesting, but otherwise I cannot think of a flaw with this game. Everything makes sense once you master it. Many recent reviews I am seeing seem to think the game is random, and the only portion that feels like that is FMX tracks, which were always a wonky addition. Thankfully they are almost nonexistent and rarely show up during the game, meaning that a large majority of the game is actually just trials the way we wanted. I recently purchased evolution and realized how far they came with this title, and I can't wait for the sequel.
EDIT: 4 years later and this game is still great. The main difference between evolution and fusion for me in the sense of gameplay is the flow of the bike. Fusion just feels smoother, with the best bike feeling like butter when you are nailing a track. I love this game and put a lot of hours into it, and I would highly recommend it. It is great.

EDIT OF EDIT: despite the release of trials rising, fusion is probably the better title overall. I would recommend this one over rising if you want are more generally positive experience, and after 300+ hours put into this game, it is still fun and I am still improving.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042779001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1458133853}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047273077', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2058, 'last_played': 1656208622}
review: If you're a fan of motorcycle racing or motorcycles in general, you should love this game.  It's sort of like a 2D Platforming Motorcycle game in a 3D environment (Somewhat like Excitebike the arcade classic, except that's a 2d environment and this is a lot mroe challenging in later tracks).  This is also a very funny game with hidden easter eggs and track challenges that can make you laugh (like chasing a penguin through a track).  This game also has cool techno-like music that I personally love.  If you aren't a fan of riding tracks but you like creating tracks/levels, this game also has a track editor included in it!  I definately reccomend this game to racing/motorcycle fans alike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085317712', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1424217271}
review:
I preordered this game a while back now and moving from Trials Evolution to this was a treat. The all new mechanics such as the tricks and adding the challenges to the singleplayer was brilliant and gave the trials experience alot more than just gaining the gold medals. 

Singleplayer is brilliant and would reccomend playing the singleplayer to anyone that owned Trials evo as you wont be dissapointed, however if your looking for a multiplayer experience, you've come to the wrong place. Local multipler has been implemented (however playing local multiplayer on a PC can be difficult) but there is no online multiplayer which is extremely dissapointing as this was one of the most fun parts of Trials evo. Hopefully this will be implemented soon as i am really looking forward to it and have been for a while now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056674521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1428047461}
review:
It's early days yet having just installed and played the intro levels but I much preferred the 2D gameplay in the early Trials games and on my iPhone at this stage.  The bikes don't feel as responsive and the camera angles can cause frustration at times in being unable to judge distance to ground and such when doing flips, etc.

Might become fun in the later levels, I'll throw another few hours into it but at this stage not high on the recommendation list if you're a fan of the originals -- if this is your first Trials game, you may enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960865806', 'num_games_owned': 2070, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1552768584}
review:
TL;DR: Be aware that Trials Fusion--at present--only supports [I]local[/I] multiplayer.

A friend and I just got copies of Trials Fusion with the express purpose of playing together just like we did in Trials Evolution (really fun game, btw). My friends all live in different states, but for years gaming has been our panacea, our social time with distant friends we may seldom see in person. Imagine our surprise when we launched the game and discovered that the only multiplayer it supports is local--as in [I]sitting-at-the-same-PC/console[/I] local.

Maybe we should have looked into it more, but after enjoying Trials Evolution's multiplayer, we made the assumption that Fusion had the same multiplayer modes. The Steam store page at present only mentions "Multi-player" and playing "with friends" but never points out the local-only limitation.

The developers have gone on record promising expanded multiplayer options in the future--and in the game's community forum promise a "Commitment to Growing and Expanding Trials Fusion"--but from what I've seen they specifically refuse to announce a date or even what multiplayer options they're considering adding. In one article they even state that "Since Trials always has a few secrets, we‚Äôll not reveal more". I guess we're just supposed to cross our fingers and hope for the best.

If online multiplayer is an important factor, it might be in buyers' interests to wait until solid information is available.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040648606', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 5481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2878, 'last_played': 1599775933}
review:
Sparen wir uns die Einleitung und kommen gleich zum wichtigen Teil.

-Bis auf die extrem Maps ist es kein Problem die Strecken beim ersten versuch meist sogar ohne Fehler durchzufahren.

-Die neuen FMX Strecken sind meiner Meinung nach √ºberhaupt keine gute neuerung, Ich habe mit diesen pers√∂nlich keinerlei Spa√ü (Zum Gl√ºck gibt es nur 4 Strecken und einen Technikparcour).

-Der neue Soundtrack ist viel schlecher als die der vorherigen.

-Nachdem ich bei meiner Trials Evolution Version aufgrund eines Bugs nicht auf die Streckenzentrale zugreifen kann, kann ich nicht beurteilen was sich dort ver√§ndert hat. Mache Communitystrecken werde monatlich? von RedLynx ausgew√§hlt und im Spiel vorgestellt (in Form einer eigenen Kategorie). Ich pers√∂nlich halte die Streckenzentrale f√ºr ein wenig un√ºbersichtlich.

-Das Spiel wird √ºber Uplay gestartet und die Ergebnisse online gespeichert. Nachdem die Ubisoft Server wohl von einem Hamster im Laufrad angetrieben werden, sind die Server √∂fters down (Rekorde gehen dann verloren).

-Man kann seinen Fahrer weiterhin einkleiden und sein Motorrad gestalten.

-Es gibt jetzt eine (nicht wirklich gute) Story, wovon man aber die Kommentatoren abstellen kann.

-Es wurden zu jeder Map bis auf die FMX und Techniparcoure jeweils 3 Nebenmissionen hinzugef√ºgt, welche teilweise eine kleine Challange darstellen und die doch recht leichten Maps ein wenig schwerer gestallten (oft aber nur so Dinge wie: "Finde den roten Knopf"!). Diese machen sehr viel Spa√ü.

Trotz der zahlreichen Nachteile ist das Spiel gro√üartig es macht genauso viel Spa√ü (abgesehen von den FMX Strecken) wie die Vorg√§nger. Wer Trials vorher schon nicht mochte, wird es jetzt auch nicht. Ich liebe diese Spiel und kann es jedem weiterempfehlen. Die fehlenden Strecken kann man sich aus der Streckenzentrale holen, wo es wirklich gute Karten in allen Schwierigkeitgraden gibt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078307593', 'num_games_owned': 1258, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1433225550}
review: I know I've only logged an hour into this game, but as a very big fan of physics-based games, I have to say this one was a let down for me. I'm not going to complain about Uplay or say that the game isn't optimised correctly, because it plays wonderfully on my system at 60 FPS, ultra settings. There's really not much to Trials Fusion other than balancing your bike over different types of bumps, landing your bike correctly, and occasionally flying through the air to the next part of the track. Now don't get me wrong, there are neat tricks, solid physics, and a great presentation along with beautiful graphics. But even on sale like I got it, I'd say the $15-20 isn't worth it. Maybe at $5. If you want an awesome physics-based game where you do more than just grind through levels by shifting your weight on a bike to get over giant hills, etc., then I'd recommend you go play Happy Wheels. It's free, you can play it on flash, there is a far greater variety in vehicles/stages, and it's just more entertaining. I really love Ubisoft, but I have to say pass on this one.

It's just the same thing again, which isn't normally that bad but.... yeah, it's too similar. How much can you really do with a motorbike game? author: {'steamid': '76561198070969838', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1684385799}
review:
Just like it's previous versions, Trials Fusion delivers challening and fun tracks that test you mentally, with satasfying results with each medal you get. For those who don't know, Trials is a game about clearing challenging tracks with Bikes as fast as possible with as few faults as possible. You gain medals and coin that go to getting you new cosmetic items for your bike and rider, and well as unlocking further tracks for you to play. In Fusion, you now no longer have to just do trials tracks, but also FMX, where you can combo tricks on your bike, building up score in the attempt to get a higher medal.

  I have this game for both the Xbox 360 and Steam, and have already put quite a few hours into it. I am most definitely content with the game, and the future it holds. It runs smoothely (In windowed, I get some frame drops), without any issues when I have other programs up, and even though it has Uplay, I don't get any of the issues I have with Assassins Creed Black Flag. 

  I definitely recommend this game, and enjoy it far more than I did with the previous installments. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198045331727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1605995911}
review:
If you loved the previous Trials games, then definitely pick this up. Absolutely amazing physics-based, controller-smashing fun that we all know and love. Combine that with an even more expansive track editor than the last game, and you have a recipe for hours of entertainment.

If you're new to the series, however, I would recommend you check out Trials Evolution first, as even though the graphics are a bit worse, the variety in the campaign maps is much more interesting. No matter which one you pick, though, you won't be disappointed.

review: RedLynx fait une nouvelle fois tr√®s fort avec ce Trials Fusion. Toujours aussi plaisant √† prendre en main, il offrira des heures de jeu, mais aussi d'arrachage de cheveux aux amateurs du genre qui trouveront l√† ce qui se fait de mieux, que ce soit pour le level design, le gameplay ou la cr√©ation de contenu. author: {'steamid': '76561198073899531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1406087313}
review:
__________________________8/10____________________________
            Trials Fusion is a great game.  Lots of fun to be had for anyone looking for a bit of a challenge.  Overall, i cannot complain much about the game for the way it runs.  The graphics aren't super next-gen amazing-ness, but they still are pretty, and in my opinion as good as it needs to be for this style game.  I've had one crash, and I'm not convinced it was the game's fault.

         As compared to the last few Trials games, it still features great challenges and a darned good selection of community maps, which gives this game near infinite playability if you enjoy how the mechanics work.  Trials has always been about challenges an lunacy to me, and while Fusion may not feature as much as the lunacy as the previous games, the challenges are abundant and ready for you to make a controller shaped dent in something near you.  When i speak of this lunacy being missing, in the last trials game i was always happy with how the maps, and events always caught you off gaurd, and said "Hey, so what if there's a war going on and a nuclear shark just tried to shoot you with laser beams, ride your bike fast ad hard!!!".  Personally, fusion lacked this kick-in-the-groin lunacy i loved so much from the previous games.

        Overall, Trials Fusion will offer you hours of challenging fun, but at times, may take itself a little too seriously as compared to the previous installations to the franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000784453', 'num_games_owned': 1982, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1399055735}
review:
Dieses Spiel ist nur leuten zu empfehlen die ab und zu mit ihren kumples an einem Pc zocken wollen da das spiel keinen Online Multiplayer hat und dadurch auch nur allein oder mit Freunden die vorbeikommen k√∂nnen Spa√ü macht!

Das spiel hat wiedermal viele level und auch recht gute und unterschiedliche schwirigkeitsgrade!

Nat√ºrlich besitzt das spiel auch wieder einen Editor der wirklich einfach zu bedienen ist und man auch die ein oder andere coole und besonders aussehende strecke bauen kann nat√ºrlich ists so einfach das auch die ein oder andere strecke von einem erbauer etwas unschaffbar sein kann oder in einem absolut falschen schwirigkeitgrad!

Die maps und strecken sind alle in einem zukunftsdesign und sind alle richtig gut und vorallem sch√∂n dargestellt mit vielen explosionen und fliegenden raumschiffen herunterfallenden gegenst√§nden und sich √∂ffnende t√ºren bvor man auf sie trifft was halt auch die recht sch√∂ne grafik des spiels zur show stellt!

Es gibt auch wieder viele unterschiedliche outfits die mit den anderen auch kombiniert werden k√∂nnen es ist so aufgebaut das man mit seinen lvln auflevelt und unterschiedliche stufen der kleidung dadurch freischalten kann und so immer mehr badass aussehen kann!

Wenn man der story/ den gespr√§chen der kampange lauscht und nicht von dem st√§ndigen wiederholen bei neustarts warnsinnig wird, wird in dem eine recht gut und auch lustig initierte story finden die fast der portal gleicht!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058954084', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1643929488}
review: I have played every other Trials game and I was very quickly dissapointed with this game.  Let's first start with optimization.    This game must have a perfect 60fps to run, because if it drops at all, even to 50fps it slows down so much that it is completely unplayable.  I have to set this game to absolute minimun settings and even then I still get massive fps drops.  And my computer can max out Battlefield 3.  Next we have the addition of the trick system.  It is the most god awful thing you can ever attempt to use.  It does not do what you tell it to do and the rider will frequently get stuck in a position.  But apart from the huge gameplay issues, the game is still just not fun or challenging.  This game is so easy that I was able to beat almost every track first try with a gold medal.  The leaning is also very unresponsive in comparison to older games.  The older games were very fun, but they totally blew it with this one.  Complete waste of $20.  Don't buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121971704', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1032, 'last_played': 1478639674}
review:
It makes me so infuriated, to the point of rage quitting and doing nothing for 2 hours, but all i can think of in those 2 hours is TRIALS.
Sure it's not perfect, not even close, but i believe RL are the type of devs that know what they're doing, unlike some (EA *ahem*)
PROS:
Addictive
low Skill floor, high skill ceiling
CONS: 
Possibly the most infuriating game i've ever played
No mp AT THE MOMENT
Custom tracks aren't cross platform yet (hopefully will be at some point)
8/10, would be a 9/10 if the track central was fixed and mp was brought in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043845006', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1474134048}
review:
I was hoping lots more fun.. after it's brother -iOS game- Trials Frontier.. I think this game is under development.. it's like a pre-beta release..

Lots of problems with graphics processor.. when all things are in "Low" .. still slow
There is no stats for Bikes.. Choosing bike for just for it's shape.. huh.
There is no stats for Bike Upgrades.. Spending money for just for shape.. nonsense..
Side missions / Track Challenges have no explanations.. No place to track them..

uPlay stil can't track the games..
It's like a investment for future of the game.. Maybe It's gonna be better in next 5 months..

If you wanna have fun, try Trials Frontier on iPad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037541199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2606, 'last_played': 1417880949}
review:
Trials Fusion in 15 minutes

http://youtu.be/HS_mC4_R0w0

Trials Fusion is a worthy addition to the team ... even though the futuristic backdrop feels a little bit against the grain of the series ... there was something special about the redneck vibe that previous games had ... but the graphics and the new types of bikes are pretty damn amazing ...

The game follows pretty much the same path as the others ... the easy tracks are really easy ... the hard tracks are really hard ... and I am yet to manage to finish an extreme track ... The addition of the FMX tracks is pretty damn cool as well ... 

I have found lots of amazing tracks on Track Central - but also some terrible ones ... and this is the way with user created content ... but I don't see myself getting bored of this game any time soon ...

Really looking forward to online multiplayer when it finially arrives ...

Worth getting ... and looking forward to the season pass DLC content too!

Slosh

author: {'steamid': '76561198002170172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2173, 'last_played': 1459096538}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973993275', 'num_games_owned': 1929, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1483138736}
review:
Synopsis: The 4th release of the 2.5D motorcross racing game with platform elements, where you shoot the best possible time with the least amount of faults/errors.
Genre: Platform Racer

Yea! Great 2.5D graphics, pick up and play for 5 minutes style, high skill ceiling, support for player created content built in at launch, lots of ways to customize your rider and bike. Very competitive leaderboard game.

Meh! Expierienced Trials veteran will find the game very easy to beat up til the Hard/Extreme tracks, skill games are now have to be unlocked and not accessible from own section, less skill games then previous games(probaly will be added via DLC). No launch SLI/Xfire support that causes performance issues.

Bleh! Uses UPLAY,some game sections take forever to load, can be very frustrating to some people that could cause rage quits. Seems to be less tracks then previous games but I could be wrong

Lowdown: If you have a few friends to play with you will have a blast competing against each other's times, which is where all the appeal is. The game also can be quite rewarding as nothing is as awesome as beating a section of the track that you had been stuck on for 100 faults.


4/5

review:
Trails Fusion spielt sich, bis auf die M√∂glichkeit jetzt auch Stunts ala Endo oder Superman machen zu k√∂nnen, wie schon von Trails HD bzw Evolution gewohnt sehr eing√§ngig. Bei den Stunteinlagen muss ich pers√∂nlich noch etwas rumprobieren, da ich noch Probleme habe diese Teilweise √ºberhaupt auszuf√ºhren oder einige mit Flip zu landen. Bei den Fahrerlizenen muss man sich √ºbrigens das teilweise doch sehr lange Gequatsche nicht anh√∂ren, da man es mit reset am letzten Checkpoint √ºberspringen kann. gef√§llt mir das man als Spieler √§lterer Trails-Games so die M√∂glichkeit hat die Fahrer√ºbungen doch recht schnell hinter sich zu bringen. Ein U-Play-Konto wird √ºbrigens gebraucht. Trotzdem konnte man schon anhand der Beta sagen...
wer Trails HD und/oder Evolution gezockt und geliebt hat, darf uneingeschr√§nkt zugreifen. Auch jedem der noch nie mit Trails HD, Evolution oder auch Fusion in Ber√ºhrung gekommen ist, spreche ich hiermit eine Empfehlung aus. Also auch wenn Ubischrott draufsteht und leider U-Play gebraucht wird (welches man aber eh hat wenn man schon mit Assassins Creed oder meinetwegen auch Herrn Fischer zu tun hatte) ist Trails Fusion nen sehr sch√∂nes St√ºck Software f√ºr das RedLynx/Ubisoft doch den ein oder anderen Taler verdient hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982232649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1399352039}
review:
The game is extremely clunky and reminds me of how much I hate Trackmania. One of the biggest, yet simplest, turn-offs is that the lean sticks. Instead of a central position where you can lean back or forward from, you have to constantly fight the lean. Oh, you stuck that landing after leaning back? Here, try this super wheelie on the ramp 10 feet in front of you.

The game looked so fun from the videos I've seen and so much promise from user-created tracks. Such a let-down.

Edit: Out of 100 games, this is the first one I've considered getting a refund. It has taken me 8 years with Steam to now realize there's no refunds. One hell of a lesson, I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4492, 'num_reviews': 1009, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1398521333}
review:
Trials Fusion is just like Trials 2 and Trials Evolution but set in a semi-futuristic world. Does it do anything new ? Apart from a couple of decent looking tracks, not really, no. Next to these new tracks you have your licenses, stunts, mini-games and character customization. All the things you would expect from a sequel. But at least it doesn't run as poorly as Evolution did.
Is it any easier ? Hell no. And [i]that's[/i] the magic of Trials.

[Rating: 82/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561198065390913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1426297262}
review:
Same old Trials, New Maps.  I fell in love with this series years ago on console, and for the most part this installment hasn't dissappointed me yet.  It's addictive. It's frustrating, but the feeling of satisfaction when you finally gold medal makes it worth the anger. The new FMX mode and 4-wheel drive vehicles add some slight variation to the old formula. The Community Track Creation has huge potential and some pretty good tracks have already been created, but sometimes the direction changes are clunky and completely throw off the feel of the tracks.

If your framerate drops below 60 the game goes into slow motion mode, which can get really annoying, but with a decent pc and nothing running in the background that won't usually be a problem. Every other review has taken care of complaining about Uplay for me so I won't bother.  No Online MP, Local only (Something tells me we can expect to have to buy a "Online Multiplayer DLC Pack" in the near future).  "Season Pass" seems awful pricey (it costs as much as the base game) so the devs better be planning some massive DLC packs to justify that price, otherwise I'm passing on that for now.   The Commentator Audio gets VERY repetitive if you get stuck on a track.

Overall, It's enjoyable with a few small flaws that can be easily looked past. If you liked any previous Trials games, or if it's on sale, you should definately buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059612240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1399708933}
review:
Trials Fusion at this time is nothing I would recommend.

The game is have some huge issue with frame rate drops, that will force you into super slowmotion.
Even though I'm well within the system requirements, set all settings to as low as possible and ran the game in windowed mode
I'm still unable to play the game smoothly.

Besides all that...
The game looks great!
The music and vibrant colors really gets you psyched to play.
Some of the annoying audio elements such as the riders voice and the announcer could be turn off which is much appreciated.

If you are way, WAY above the system requirements then buy this game!
Otherwise, do and be hopeful for a patch addressing the major issues or.... Just don't buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977252578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1399849586}
review:
The Bad:
- BEWARE, this uses DRM in the form of uPlay, and does not tell you this anywhere prior to purchasing despite what some have said; very, very misleading.
 
- Having to sign into two separate accounts every time just to be able to play the game (Steam and uPlay).

- uPlay achievements instead of Steam achievements, even though it was bought on Steam - again it tells you this nowhere prior to purchasing.

- Game physics seem tempermental at times, especially compared to all previous games which were almost consistently correct e.g. your bike can clip into the world forcing you to crash every now and again, or random unexpected bounces or rotations that don't feel right.

- Game feels slightly unfinished e.g. still no online capabilities, and bikes not loading at all in the bike selection screen.

- A good few of the Individual track challenges are stupidly frustrating beyond belief.

- Shorter tracks than previous games.

- No custom resolutions.

- Crosses the fine line between challenging and frustrating.


The Good:
- Significantly better visuals.

- Customisation.

- Individual Track Challenges.

- Not a bad PC port.


All in all the game is good and fun, albeit hair pullingly frustrating if you want to complete everything. A big problem is uPlay and the fact you're duped into using it or else you've wasted your money.

review: Welcome to the future! I have not played earlier trials games so I can't compare them to this game but overall I'm not a huge fan. I was led to this game by the app trials fronteir. I did enjoy the app but for anyone who thinks this game is like the app it is not. I was hoping to be able to upgrade the individual bikes a little more but you just get the bike. The only thing you can change is the way the bike looks, but not the actual traction of wheels or engine or anything else. And there are only a few bikes to choose from. It's a fun game to play every now and then but I can't see myself committing more than 30 minutes at a time to this game.

review: Pienso que Ubisoft deber√≠a esforzarse m√°s en optimizar el juego para equipos antiguos, si tu tarjeta gr√°fica es antigua, m√°s o menos del 2008, 2009, el juego no arrancar√°, deber√≠an optimizarlo para DirectX 9.0 y Shader Model 3.0 aunque funcione con mucho lag incluso a m√≠nimos recursos y la resoluci√≥n m√°s baja, al menos que arranque, solo recomiendo este juego a gente con un PC que tenga mucha potencia gr√°fica, memoria RAM suficiente y un procesador en condiciones, es decir, que vaya un poco por delante de los requisitos de sistema, si no, a la hora de iniciar el juego se quedar√° en pantalla negra y pocos segundos despu√©s saldr√° "Trials_Fusion.exe ha dejado de funcionar" o se iniciar√°, pero cuando inicies un nivel se cerrar√° mostrando el mismo mensaje, una pena que no funcione en PCs antiguos con lo chulo que est√° el juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027022258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 7, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1710168714}
review:
Having played every Trials game since 2, i've seen the series go from warehouses to the great outdoors and now to the future and with every iteration, it gets better and better. Trials Fusion pretty much kept what made Evolution great and added a few things to keep it from being just another Trials game. Here's my verdict.

The GOOD.

-"WELCOME TO THE FUTURE....MAN, MACHINE, THE FUTURE!"...yeah MUCH better intro than "VROOM VROOM, im ready to go, time for the muh muh muh muh muh muhnday nitro!"

-Trials and Tribulations: The easy to learn, hard to master gameplay is still here and still as good as its ever been.

-HOLY EPIC PC PORT BATMAN!: Redlynx learned from their mistakes, a much better port than Evo was. No texture pop in, no long load times, no FPS studdering all while adding a lot of graphics options to cater to many different setups. Nothing but good, clean, beautiful visuals at 60fps.(up to 120 would've been great though)

-Challenging: The new challenge system adds ALOT of replay value to each track, although after beating Inferno IV, i don't wanna ever do that again. But its nice to go back and do 15 backflips on a track or finding that secret entrance or play tennis with a penguin to get XP for that fancy body kit you want.

Here's my Inferno IV results if you don't believe me: http://cloud-4.steampowered.com/ugc/3332972269309505928/43D7B8AAF0EA94C165A622603A4DBFCDEECC01C2/

The MEH.

-Tricky: The FMX system is nice...but finicky, i've used keyboard(my main setup) and a PS4 controller and no matter what i do, i can never get it to do the trick i want to do during FMX events(Especially the ones that ask you to do specific tricks), i can only do coffins...EVERY TIME! Frustrating at times but a neat little addition nonetheless.

-From an easy stroll to a trip to hell: As a long time player, i've gained a bit of skill over the years. I can gold(and above) every track up to the Rainforest bit, with ease(minus challenges). But after that, man does it go from easy to hard in an instant, i feel like newcomers are gonna have more problems adjusting to the difficulty curve than i did. At first its all about high speed and looking cool, after the ATV section...its all about control and balance, ESPECIALLY after unlocking the Pit Viper.

-Do i look pretty?: Customization options are here, but a bit lacking, you can't operate on individual bike parts anymore(in favor of body kits) the rider customization is Tiered and in different themes and you can only change out the helmet, the shirt and the legs. Which kinda sucks, but there's alot to unlock and each tier is better than the last.

The BAAAAAD.

-Aside from the FMX, there really isn't anything new.

Conclusion: Its Trials, if you've never played one, do yourself a favor and pick this up, this is by far one of the best arcade series out there. If you're a fan and you needed more Trials, click that buy button.

Hopefully some good community content will fill in the gaps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001604367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1408051265}
review:
Meine Empfehlung in diesem Fall ist nicht uneingeschr√§nkt. Fusion ist vor allem mehr vom bereits Bekannten. Mehr Strecken mit neuem, sehr coolen, Setting. Die positiven Punkte lassen sich fast allesamt von Evolution Gold √ºbernehmen.

Positiv zu erw√§hnen ist das im Gegensatz zu Evolution die Performance wesentlich stabiler ist. Auch wenn es hier und da zum nachladen der Texturen kommt(nach dem heutigen Stand der Technik unverst√§ndlich).
Negativ zu erw√§hnen sind da jedoch ein paar Punkte:
- der Soundtrack ist, naja, schlicht doof
- keine User generierten Supercross Strecken (f√ºr mich enorm wichtiger Punkt)
- kein Online Multiplayer (ok f√ºr mich jetzt nicht so wichtig)
- die neue Tricksteuerung ist so ungenau das sie schon wieder nervt
- man braucht auch wenn man es √ºber Steam gekauft hat Uplay (meine Fresse das nervt, immerhin startet das Spiel direkt und Uplay bietet sich selbst nach beenden zum Abschuss an)

Den Umfang habe ich als Punkt extra ausgelassen da Evolution Gold ja nicht ein sondern 2 Spiele war. Wobei hier schon arg auff√§llt wie Ubisoft √ºberdeutlich auf die DLCs hindeutet. Gepsielt wurde nur mit Gamepad, kann also nichts zur Tastatursteuerung sagen.

Da die Unterschiede so marginal sind beschr√§nke ich mich auch auf diese. Jemandem der noch kein Trials gespielt hat empfehle ich auf jeden Fall eher Evolution Gold und nur dem Fan dann auch Fusion.

Note pour moi m√™me, faut arreter d'acheter des jeux sur un coup de t√™te, car celui la, bien que plaisant et mettant mes nerfs √† l'√©preuve, finira dans mon cimeti√®re vid√©oludique une fois la camapgne finie ( 3h de jeu, d√©ja a +50% , bon m√™me si bien sur les niveaux se durcisse donc j'en ai encore pour quelques heures) .....

review: Trials Fusion is a great game for fans of previous Trials games and newcomers to the series. The tracks are challenging, the editor is powerful (if a bit hard to use), and the community is rapidly expanding. There are the occasional glitches (seed builds will crash your game without fail), but it harldy detracts from the overall experience (except for seed buildings NOT FUCKING WORKING). Overall I would recommend this game, but it does need some bug fixes (please fix seed buildings).

Great Game and great gameplay!

Overall for $20 your getting an extremly well made game that would satisfy all your trials needs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025164697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1416095840}
review: I was really looking forward to playing Trials Fusion but in its current form the game is simply broken. The game speed is fixed to the frame rate which I assume is because it is a (rather bad) PS / XBox port. So if the framerate drops from 60 to 40 it runs at 2/3 of the correct speed. This means that a) you need a superb gaming system (forget about the minimum requirements) and b) all comparisons to other players or friends are complete bs. This is a reaction-based game, yet anyone can just crank up the graphics and play in slow motion, taking twice as long to position the rider. Apparently the developers are working on this but I recommend you stay away from the PC version until this is fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004342277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1398632722}

review: Probbaly a little less content than previous Trials with a higher price tag but Redlynx swore to support the game post launch with free content (and of course paid DLC), multiplayer is abcent at the moment but it's supposed to be patched in weeks from launch. author: {'steamid': '76561197991412799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1459631378}
review:
7/10 - Honestly rather dissapointing

The length of the singleplayer is rather short weighing in at about 3 hours with little to no retries, obtaining mostly gold and silver medals. Their new FMX mechanic is unintuitive at best, boiling down to flailing the right joystick in hopes it counts as you performing a trick with little rhyme and reason. The game is relying on the user created tracks to increase its longevity, which is not a bad thing but expect to pay for their DLC to continue playing their community tracks as it will most likely be required.

Pros:
-Still the same great Trials game
-User created maps
-Very pretty visuals and effects

Cons:
-Expect semi-required DLC
-FMX is unintuitive
-Short singleplayer experience

review:
I need to rewrite my review, because I finally bought the Awesome Level MAX DLC and this changed all. If you like wacky crazy stuff you will love the Awesome Level MAX story, but for people like me who adore Trials Evolution the included Redlynx VS All-Stars Maps are what you wanted. Sure it's not much to play, but the quality of the maps and level design is top notch. The base game and season pass is kinda lame. It is more like a show off "look what we can achieve with Ubisoft" and was way too much. This DLC is like Evolution. Would love to see more content like that :)


OLD REVIEW:
Yes it is a Trials game, but in my eyes it could be better and can't top what Trials Evolution did in 2012 :( It's a huge disappointment compared to Evolution.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964750054', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1422201725}
review:
Du trial comme on l'aime. Le jeu reprend le comportement de son ain√© pour ce qui est des v√©hicule en y ajoutant le quad (un peu inutile de mon point de vu) et les figures.
On notera aussi que les jeux d'aresse ont cette fois-ci √©t√© inclu dans les diff√©rentes campagnes.
Le jeu introduit √©galement un syst√®me de classement et de niveau mais surtout la possibilit√© de jouer √† desmaps cr√©er sur les plateformes consoles et vice versa.
L'√©diteur lui est toujours pr√©sent et tr√®s complet permettant de r√©aliser √† peu pr√®s n'importe quoi.

Le seul petit b√©mole vient de l'optimisation des ressources, car certe il tourne sur des machines relativement pauvres au minimum mais au maximum il demande des ressources que les graphismes ne justifient pas toujours.

Bref un tr√®s bon cru qu'il faut au moins essayer.

review: The game is like an ipad game moved to the PC, it only runs in so little resolution that its like playing on the ipad but i cant forcefully press my fingers on the screen, unless its me trying to smash that little faggot's head in the main menu out of frustration. I feel like an idiot staring at the tiny screen that the game runs on and it doesnt help that the rest of the game wont run at normal speed unless it looks like pong and trials HD had gay sex in a back alley. I dont think anybody should buy this game due to my problem but who gives a fuck Trials can shit in a potato, cook it for 5 hours and slam it in a case and name it Trails Fusion and everybody wil buy it anyways.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980250426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1400377114}
review:
This should have been dlc for the last game. This game is way easier than the last and you never feel like you have to hold out on a level for a silver or gold because a)you always seem to have the medals to progress and b) you always seem to get silvers and golds anyway. Yes there is a connection between these two things but it just means that the game is not challenging enough. It wasn't until the "hard" levels that I really even felt like I had to do much at all with the controls. 

Sure, they give you ATVs and tricks but it doesn't mean much in the end. The ATV doesn't amke much of a difference gameplay-wise and the tricks are clumsily implementented.

For players who haven't played Trials, go play Evolution Gold Edition or maybe the previous games (I don't know, only played Evolution). I'd pay $5-10 for this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010333071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1398891053}
review:
As other people have described, Uplay is the pubic hair in this otherwise fantastic entree. No experience with the previous Trials games is necessary to instantly (well, after dealing with Uplay) enjoy this game. 

Unlike traditional racing games, there is no steering. You control only acceleration, braking, and leaning on your supercharged motorcross bike, in an attempt to finish insane levels or interesting challenges. Before you know it, you'll be mashing the convenient "instantly restart level" or "instantly restart at checkpoint" buttons as you try to figure out how to get just a little more air off that one jump, how to avoid faceplanting on that log, or how to keep up with your friend's ghosts. It is easy to get caught up in the search for perfection on each level because the gameplay is so tight, fun, and rewarding. 

Highly recommend! WELCOME TO THE FUUTURE

author: {'steamid': '76561198017660848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1418084735}
review:
Trials Fusion is an excellent entry to the series. Here's why:

RedLynx tried something different this time around, and it works quite well. The trick system is an excellent feature put into the game. It promotes replayability of tracks by having the user see how "flashy" of a run they can nail and show off to their friends. It's based off of the famous RedLynx physics engine, making it intuitive, nice to look at, and at some points, silly to observe what may happen during a crash.

But beyond the trick system, there's even more in terms of the traditional trials game. There's the usual spike in difficulty, where the last few groups of levels WILL test your patience, skill, and sanity. The levels themselves still keep their usual charm; being put in wacky/amazing environments, seeing things interact around you, it's all here. The environments all look great and there's enough variety to keep you happy.

Now there are trick runs, where you have to see how many points you can get on a special track designated for this new system. I like this, because sometimes you want to do tricks on the normal tracks, but you know it may hurt your time. It seems they're trying to cater to those who like to have a little fun in between the serious time trials, and I respect their approach to it. It works for them.

Skill games are back, and they're as fun and silly as ever. I don't agree how they made them a requirement this time around, but it's not the biggest issue in the world

Each of the bikes actually has a specific purpose and will be used depending on which track you're participating in. This is WONDERFUL. I remember in evolution you would use one or two bikes, because the only things the new ones did was have more power. I REALLY appreciate RedLynx making each bike unique and useable. 

There's some really nice biker customization as well. Lots of cool, future-y outfits to choose from. 

I'm really excited excited to see where the DLC takes this game. Although the game had a less-than-stellar launch, I'm still very happy with this product, and cannot wait to play through more trials. It feels like a trials game through-and-through to me, and that's what matters. It's a quality product that will only get better with more tweaking and additional content. I believe this is completely worth your money if you are a fan of the series.
